campaign_city: New Ireland Province, Papua New Guinea

story:
Short Summary

My name is Gideon Commey, an environmental activist and renewable energy entrepreneur based in Ghana. I run a solar start-up in Ghana, "Solar People," with the vision of deploying solar lighting solutions to rural and off-grid communities. I am also a Climate Reality Leader personally trained by Al Gore. Last fall, I worked as a Climate Fellow with 350VT through the Community Solutions Program (CSP) of the US State Department.

According to a Lighting Africa Report of 2012, 72% of people in rural Ghana depend on kerosene as the main source of lighting. Kerosene lanterns are expensive to fuel, injurious to health and likely to cause household fires.

My campaign is to replace kerosene lanterns from the homes of school going children in rural communities in Ghana by replacing them with solar lamps. This campaign is very important to me because I see energy poverty as a climate justice issue that must be tackled from the grassroots. Besides, solar lamps gives 15x more illumination than kerosene lanterns, are cost effective and double the number of study hours available to school children. 

What We Need & What You Get

Our target for this campaign is $10,000. This amount can replace more than 300 kerosene lanterns with solar lamps. What a transformation! If you ever lived in a village without lights to use in the evening to study, this will mean everything to you, it will change your world. I have seen this before in the village of Opintin where I spent the night with children studying with their new solar lamps. I was moved to tears.

Guess what? We have incredible gifts for everyone who donates. Not just any gift but amazing souvenirs from Ghana, the gateway to Africa. Maybe you haven't visited our beautiful country and continent before but you will hopefully get to feel our culture in the eyes of these gifts just to express our gratitude.

If we don't reach our target of $10,000, we won't despair. We will make the best out of what we raise. At Solar People, we believe in using less to deliver more!

The Impact

Donating to give a child in rural Ghana a solar lamp has real life consequences.The benefits of these lamps are immense: primary school grades can jump from mere 50% to 100%, burn risks and carbon emissions are reduced to zero, income generating capacity increases dramatically, livelihood improves dramatically and off-grid families extend their day by more than 3 extra hours. You will be making a huge difference in the life of a child in Ghana no matter where you live.

A couple of months ago, we replaced 21 kerosene lanterns in a village called Opintin in rural Ghana with support from friends in 350VT. This track record gives impetus to this project as we hope to scale it up to reach several hundreds in 3 more regions in Ghana.

Risks & Challenges

There are so many challenges with a project of this sort. In the past, we have encountered situations where parents and relatives compete with children to use the solar lamps at night because the entire community lives in darkness. While children want to use them to study, others would want to use them to cook dinner or perform other chores.

We have resolved this by visiting the homes of pupils and having an open conversation with their families to make them understand the need to encourage children to use them to study rather than for any other purpose. In the long term, we hope to power villages entirely on solar energy from the sun so every member of the community can have access to electricity. 

Other Ways You Can Help

There are so many ways you can help aside donating. Please share this link to your friends and network on all social media platforms- Facebook, Twitter, etc so people can donate. You can also create and send bulk emails on our behalf. Help us to get the message out there. We will appreciate it! Thank you!!
story_txt:
Short Summary 
My name is Gideon Commey, an environmental activist and renewable energy entrepreneur based in Ghana. I run a solar start-up in Ghana, "Solar People," with the vision of deploying solar lighting solutions to rural and off-grid communities. I am also a Climate Reality Leader personally trained by Al Gore. Last fall, I worked as a Climate Fellow with 350VT through the Community Solutions Program (CSP) of the US State Department.According to a Lighting Africa Report of 2012, 72% of people in rural Ghana depend on kerosene as the main source of lighting. Kerosene lanterns are expensive to fuel, injurious to health and likely to cause household fires.My campaign is to replace kerosene lanterns from the homes of school going children in rural communities in Ghana by replacing them with solar lamps. This campaign is very important to me because I see energy poverty as a climate justice issue that must be tackled from the grassroots. Besides, solar lamps gives 15x more illumination than kerosene lanterns, are cost effective and double the number of study hours available to school children.    What We Need & What You Get Our target for this campaign is $10,000. This amount can replace more than 300 kerosene lanterns with solar lamps. What a transformation! If you ever lived in a village without lights to use in the evening to study, this will mean everything to you, it will change your world. I have seen this before in the village of Opintin where I spent the night with children studying with their new solar lamps. I was moved to tears.
Guess what? We have incredible gifts for everyone who donates. Not just any gift but amazing souvenirs from Ghana, the gateway to Africa. Maybe you haven't visited our beautiful country and continent before but you will hopefully get to feel our culture in the eyes of these gifts just to express our gratitude.
If we don't reach our target of $10,000, we won't despair. We will make the best out of what we raise. At Solar People, we believe in using less to deliver more!   The Impact
Donating to give a child in rural Ghana a solar lamp has real life consequences.The benefits of these lamps are immense: primary school grades can jump from mere 50% to 100%, burn risks and carbon emissions are reduced to zero, income generating capacity increases dramatically, livelihood improves dramatically and off-grid families extend their day by more than 3 extra hours. You will be making a huge difference in the life of a child in Ghana no matter where you live. A couple of months ago, we replaced 21 kerosene lanterns in a village called Opintin in rural Ghana with support from friends in 350VT. This track record gives impetus to this project as we hope to scale it up to reach several hundreds in 3 more regions in Ghana.
    Risks & Challenges There are so many challenges with a project of this sort. In the past, we have encountered situations where parents and relatives compete with children to use the solar lamps at night because the entire community lives in darkness. While children want to use them to study, others would want to use them to cook dinner or perform other chores.
We have resolved this by visiting the homes of pupils and having an open conversation with their families to make them understand the need to encourage children to use them to study rather than for any other purpose. In the long term, we hope to power villages entirely on solar energy from the sun so every member of the community can have access to electricity. 
    Other Ways You Can Help
There are so many ways you can help aside donating. Please share this link to your friends and network on all social media platforms- Facebook, Twitter, etc so people can donate. You can also create and send bulk emails on our behalf. Help us to get the message out there. We will appreciate it! Thank you!!

story:
TO READ / PER LEGGERE IN ITALIANO / LER EM PORTUGUÊS

SCROLL DOWN / SCORRI GIU' / ROLAR PARA BAIXO

https://www.facebook.com/direitosdepapel/

https://www.instagram.com/direitosdepapel/

 

ENG

Supporting this project you can achieve two goals in a single act: the production of a video-documentary and the start-up of a coffee plantation in the quilombola community of Linharinho. And maybe in a very close future you could receive the best coffee you have ever invested in!

Obrigado for your help.

In the Sapê do Norte, in the state of Espírito Santo, Brazil, the local people of Quilombolas - descendants of black slaves - are marginalized and eradicated, along with the local flora, by corporations of paper and oil, a scenario sadly common to many other areas on the planet where monoculture is dominant over local cultures, ecosystems and biodiversity.

The 'Retomadas', the Quilombola re-appropriations, are formed by people living in the quilombo (place of refuge) and that are surrounded by eucalyptus and sugar cane monocultures and oil stations. In these areas, communities work to reconvert soil, increasing biodiversity, which has suffered degradation, deforestation and pollution for over fifty years; trying to produce healthy, sustainable food that will ensure their survival in their native lands.

In the '70s, the Norwegian corporation Aracruz, now a brazilian company with the name of Fibria - world's first producer of cellulose and paper - illegally bought vast areas of tropical forest from the dictatorship to promote the idea of development based on large-scale monoculture. Eucalyptus, native of Australia, thanks to the warm climate, in Brazil reaches 25m in only six years. Along with soy and sugar cane, is one of the great crops of brazilian agribusiness, which takes millions of hectares of ancient land and historically populated by indigenous peoples and Quilombolas, as in the case of Sapê do Norte region.

There are 1,200 families living in the region (12,000 in the '70s), but life in this green desert of plants is difficult. The Quilombola people lived on subsistence: they hunted, fished, harvested fruit and medicines and farmed the land in one of the most fertile areas of the planet. But today nothing grows among eucalyptus trees. Eucalyptus monoculture makes the soil poor, drains watercourses and contaminates with pesticides and herbicides used in plantations destroying biodiversity.

The Brazilian Constitution declares that these lands belong to traditional peoples and that it's duty of the state to recognize their property, giving priority and guaranteeing subsistence activities. The case of the illegal presence of Fibria in Quilombola territory represents yet another case of corruption and failure of public policies in Brazil.

Food traditions are getting lost. The nutritional values of a diversified food and the result of the ground work as well. Along with dendê oil, cassava manioc plant and the simple daily rice and beans, the cultivation of these foods is in danger. Today, the presence of eucalyptus monoculture in the lands of Sapê do Norte is identified as the main cause of food and nutrition insecurity in these communities. The processing of land use has caused an intense process of deconstruction of traditional ways of life and of agri-ecological production system that guaranteed a diversified and abundant diet. This situation has led to a high degree of monetary dependence among households: most of food currently consumed is bought in stores in neighbouring cities.

The Project

The brazilian background reported in the documentary aims to offer a starting point for reflecting on the great strength of bottom-up movements and on populations that fight against economic interests of corporations and governments with corrupt democracies.

Joice and Antonio live in the community of Linharinho, where they were born. But for over twenty years they have been struggling to have their place to live. The village was invaded by monoculture of eucalyptus, which dried rivers, extinct animals, poisoned people and led the conflict. Here, along with many others, they try to resist and heal a land that belongs to them.

Food security is threatened by the lack of a healthy food supply. Sustainable agriculture and local traditions are being compromised in the name of profit. The livelihoods of the inhabitants are rapidly decreasing. 

Joice and Antonio, with their children, have 'retomado' (taken back) a land dominated by eucalyptus to build their home and their agri-ecological project: a small permacultural coffee productive system. An ecological experimentation to produce coffee - a historical culture of tropical areas - through sustainable practices of consociation, biofertilizers, soil nutrition and increase of soil fertility, in order to have a return to an ecological production of a local product.

Joice says: -"he "Agricoltura Agroecológica goal is to produce, in the medium term, coffee and other plants from family agriculture of the highest quality using land resources for a healthy and sustainable food quality"

The earth is ready. In recent months, the soil has been prepared to accommodate coffee plants, providing organic matter and preventing erosion, soil runoff and combating evapotranspiration. Completely natural production will also ensure higher market yields.

There are hoes and the season is coming up: Help Joice and Antonio for their first harvest! Support the cause and help promote the right to food security!

You can support the project with a contribution and the budget you want.

 

Anyone who choose to support this project, regardless of the amount donated, will be included in the credits with a huge Thank you for contributing to the project success.

The project is an independent development, almost totally self-financed!
Part of the funds raised to support us will be used to cover administration costs, insurance cover for transports and technical equipment and all the other extraordinary expenses.

Support of those who believe that independent information is today more than ever a good "investment" is crucial

Support us and we will be grateful for that,

Thanks to All!

If you are interested and want to go into that, click here:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quilombola

http://www.hlrn.org/news.php?id=p2hoZw==#.Wt5KitNuZQI

https://ejatlas.org/conflict/eucalyptus-plantations-aracruz-celulose-brazil

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4266456/

 

Who we are?

Simone Tinelli

Cooperation worker, he studied sustainable territorial development and permaculture focusing on rural development projects related to family farming.
He's been following the Quilombolas struggle and the recognition of their lands since 2011. In recent years he collaborated with the brazilian NGO FASE to study sustainable territorial development programs aimed at promoting agriecological techniques in small-scale cultivation and cultural recognition of local traditions.

Andrea Corrao

He has worked in video editing and production field, he approaches for the first time the world of NGOs and international cooperation, with an increasing interest in permaculture, sustainable living practices and knowledge of situations of environmental racism and exploitation dynamics of indigenous communities around the world.

 

 

ITA

CAFFÈ SOSTENIBILE NELLE PIANTAGIONI DI EUCALIPTO

Aiuta la comunità Quilombola che soffre di insicurezza alimentare a causa dell'industria della carta.

 

 

Sostenendo questo progetto contribuirai a due obiettivi con un solo gesto: verrà prodotto un video-documentario sulla situazione drammatica delle comunità brasiliane espropriate delle proprie terre e verrà avviata una piantagione di caffè nella comunità quilombola di Linharinho. E forse in un futuro molto vicino potresti ricevere anche il miglior caffè in cui tu abbia mai investito!

Obrigado per il tuo aiuto!

Nel Brasile dei disordini socio-politici e delle continue pressioni che minacciano l’Amazzonia, molte persone e foreste native hanno dovuto lasciare il posto alla monocoltura di eucalipto.

Perchè? Per produrre la cellulosa, materia prima della carta che utilizziamo tutti i giorni: fogli, carta igienica, riviste, carta fotografica.

Dove? Nel Sapê do Norte, nello stato di Espírito Santo, in Brasile, dove le popolazioni locali dei Quilombola sono emarginate ed estirpate, insieme alla flora locale, dalle multinazionali della carta e del petrolio; uno scenario purtroppo comune a molte altre zone del pianeta dove la monocultura si impone prepotentemente su culture, ecosistemi e biodiversità locali.

Le retomadas, le riappropriazioni Quilombola, sono formate da persone che vivono nel quilombo (luogo di rifugio) e che sono circondate dalle monocolture di eucalipto e canna da zucchero e dalle stazioni petrolifere. In queste aree, le comunità lavorano per la riconversione del suolo, aumentando la biodiversità che da oltre cinquant’anni soffre degradazione, deforestazione e inquinamento. Cercando di produrre un cibo sano, sostenibile e che ne garantisca la sopravvivenza nelle loro terre native.

Negli anni ‘70 la multinazionale norvegese Aracruz, ora impresa brasiliana col nome di Fibria - prima produttrice mondiale di cellulosa e carta, acquista illegalmente dalla dittatura vaste zone di foresta tropicale per promuovere l'idea di sviluppo basato sulla monocoltura in larga scala.

Grazie al clima favorevole, in Brasile questa pianta raggiunge 25m in soli sei anni. L’eucalipto, insieme alla soia e alla canna da zucchero, è una delle grandi colture dell'agrobusiness brasiliano che si prende milioni di ettari di terre antiche e storicamente occupate da popolazioni indigene o discendenti di schiavi neri, i quilombola, come nel caso della regione del Sapê do Norte.

Nella regione vivono 1.200 famiglie (erano 12.000 negli anni '70), ma la vita in questo deserto verde di piante è difficile. Le popolazioni quilombola vivevano di sussistenza: cacciavano, pescavano, raccoglievano i frutti e coltivavano la terra di una delle zone più fertili del pianeta. Ma oggi tra gli eucalipti non cresce niente. La monocoltura di eucalipto lascia il terreno povero, prosciuga i corsi d’acqua e inquina con i pesticidi ed erbicidi usati nelle piantagioni.

La Costituzione dichiara che la terra appartiene alle popolazioni tradizionali e che è dovere dello stato riconoscerne la proprietà, dando precedenza e garantendo le attività di sussistenza. Il caso della presenza illegale della Fibria in territorio quilombola rappresenta l'ennesimo caso di corruzione e fallimento delle politiche pubbliche in Brasile.

Le tradizioni alimentari stanno andando perse. I valori nutritivi di un cibo diversificato e frutto del lavoro della terra pure. Insieme all’olio di dendê, alla manioca e al semplice e quotidiano riso e fagioli la coltivazione di questi alimenti è in pericolo. Oggi la presenza della monocoltura di eucalipto nelle terre del Sapê do Norte è individuata come prima causa di insicurezza alimentare e nutrizionale di tali comunità. La trasformazione d’uso della terra ha causato un intenso processo di destrutturazione dei modi di vita tradizionali e del sistema di produzione agroecologico che garantiva un’alimentazione diversificata e abbondante. Questa situazione ha portato le famiglie ad una grande dipendenza monetaria: la maggior parte degli alimenti consumati attualmente viene comprata nei supermercati delle città vicine.

il Progetto

Il contesto brasiliano riportato nel documentario intende offrire un punto di partenza per riflettere sulla grande forza dei movimenti dal basso verso l'alto e sulle popolazioni che lottano contro gli interessi economici delle imprese e dei governi con democrazie corrotte.

Joice e Antonio vivono nella comunità di Linharinho, dove sono nati. Ma per oltre vent'anni hanno lottato per avere il loro posto dove vivere. Il villaggio è stato invaso dalla monocoltura di eucalipto, che ha prosciugato fiumi, estinto animali, avvelenato la popolazione e innescato il conflitto. Qui, insieme a molti altri, cercano di resistere e guarire una terra che appartiene a loro.

   

La sicurezza alimentare è minacciata dalla mancanza di un approvvigionamento alimentare sano. L'agricoltura sostenibile e le tradizioni locali vengono compromesse in nome del profitto. I mezzi di sussistenza degli abitanti stanno rapidamente diminuendo. 

Joice e Antonio, con i loro figli, hanno "retomado" (ripreso, rioccupato) una terra dominata dall'eucalipto per costruire la loro casa e il loro progetto agro-ecologico: un piccolo sistema produttivo permaculturale di caffè. Una sperimentazione ecologica per produrre caffè -coltura storica di queste aree tropicali - attraverso pratiche sostenibili di consociazione, biofertilizzanti, nutrimento del suolo e aumento della fertilità, al fine di tornare alla produzione ecologica di un prodotto locale.

Joice dice: "L'obiettivo di Agricoltura Agroecológica è quello di produrre, nel medio termine, caffè e altre piante da agricoltura familiare di altissima qualità utilizzando le risorse del territorio per una qualità alimentare sana e sostenibile".

La terra è pronta. Negli ultimi mesi, il suolo è stato preparato per accogliere le piante di caffè, fornendo materia organica e prevenendo l'erosione, il dilavamento del suolo e combattendo contro l'evapotraspirazione. Una produzione completamente naturale garantirà anche rese di mercato più elevate.

Ci sono le zappe e la stagione sta arrivando: Aiuta Joice e Antonio per il loro primo raccolto! Sostieni la causa e aiuta a promuovere il diritto alla sicurezza alimentare!

Puoi sostenere il progetto con il contributo e il budget che desideri.

Chiunque scelga di sostenere questo progetto, indipendentemente dall'importo donato, sarà incluso nei crediti con un grande ringraziamento per aver contribuito al successo del progetto.

Il progetto è uno sviluppo indipendente, quasi totalmente autofinanziato!
Una parte dei fondi raccolti a nostro sostegno sarà utilizzata per coprire i costi amministrativi, la copertura assicurativa per i trasporti e le attrezzature tecniche e tutte le altre spese straordinarie.

Il sostegno di coloro che credono che l'informazione indipendente sia oggi più che mai un buon "investimento" è fondamentale

Appoggiaci e te ne saremo grati,

Grazie a tutti!

Se ti interessa e vuoi approfondire l'argomento clicca qui:

https://it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quilombo

http://www.hlrn.org/news.php?id=p2hoZw==#.Wt5KitNuZQI

https://ejatlas.org/conflict/eucalyptus-plantations-aracruz-celulose-brazil

 

Chi siamo?

Simone Tinelli

Cooperante di formazione, ha studiato sviluppo sostenibile del territorio e permacultura focalizzandosi in progetti di sviluppo rurale legati all’agricoltura familiare. Segue la lotta dei Quilombola e il riconoscimento delle loro terre dal 2011. In questi anni ha collaborato con la ONG brasiliana FASE sullo studio di programmi di sviluppo territoriale sostenibile volti a promuovere pratiche agroecologiche nelle coltivazioni di piccola scala e al riconoscimento culturale delle tradizioni locali.

Andrea Corrao

Ha lavorato nel mondo della produzione video, si avvicina per la prima volta al mondo delle ONG e della cooperazione internazionale, con un interesse sempre più crescente per la permacultura, le pratiche del vivere sostenibile e la conoscenza delle situazioni di razzismo ambientale e di dinamiche di sfruttamento delle comunità autoctone in giro per il mondo.

 

BRA

No Brasil dos protestos sociopolíticos e das contínuas pressões que ameaçam a Amazônia, muitas pessoas e florestas tiveram que deixar o passo para a monocultura de eucalipto.

Porque? Para produzir celulose, a matéria-prima do papel que utilizamos cada dia: folhas, papel higiênico, magazines, papel fotográfico.

No Sapê do Norte, no estado do Espírito Santo, onde as populações locais Quilombolas são continuamente marginalizadas e extirpadas, junto com a flora local, pelas multinacionais de papel e petróleo; um cenário infelizmente comum em várias regiões do planeta onde a monocultura se impõe fortemente sobre culturas, ecossistemas e biodiversidade locais.

A retomada quilombola, é formada por pessoas que vivem no quilombo ( lugar de refugio), e que estão cercados pelo monocultivo de eucalipto(celulose), cana de açúcar,complexo petroleiro, empresas que oprime todas comunidades que aqui existem, muitas famílias já foram embora de várias localidades, temos muitas escassez de água, as retomadas quilombolas são áreas que estão sendo retomadas pelos quilombolas e nestas áreas vem sendo feito vários trabalhos de reconversão de solo, solo estes que por mais de 50 anos sofreram com a degradação, desmatamentos, contaminação do solo, dentre outros, enumeras famílias tem trabalhado para conseguir tirar alimentos de boa qualidade e sustentável dessas áreas para sobreviverem.

Nos anos 70, em tempos de governo ditatorial, a multinacional norueguêsa Aracruz - agora empresa brasileira com o nome de Fibria, primeira produtora mundial de celulose e papel - compra ilegalmente da ditadura várias áreas de floresta nativa para promover a ideia de desenvolvimento baseada na monocultura em grande escala.

Graças ao clima favorável, no Brasil esta planta atinge 25m em apenas seis anos. O eucalipto, junto com a soja e a cana de açúcar, é um dos maiores cultivos do agronegócio brasileiro, tomando milhões de hectares de terras antigas e historicamente ocupadas por populações indígenas ou quilombolas, como no caso da região do Sapê do Norte.

Na região  moram 1.200 famílias (12.000 nos anos ‘70), mas a vida nesse deserto verde de plantas é difícil. As populações quilombolas viviam de subsistência: elas caçavam, pescavam, recolhiam os frutos e cultivavam a terra de uma das áreas mais férteis do planeta. Mas hoje em dia nada cresce entre os eucaliptos. Este monocultivo deixa o solo pobre, seca os rios e polui com pesticidas e herbicidas usados nas plantações.

A Constituição declara que a terra pertence às populações tradicionais e que é dever do Estado reconhecer a propriedade, favorecendo e garantindo as atividades de subsistência. O caso da presença ilegal da Fibria em território quilombola representa mais um caso de corrupção e falha das políticas públicas no Brasil.

As tradições alimentares estão se perdendo. Os valores nutritivos de uma comida diversificada e fruto do trabalho da terra também. Junto com o óleo de dendê, a mandioca e o cotidiano arroz e feijão, o cultivo destes alimentos está em perigo. Hoje a presença do monocultura de eucalipto nas terras do Sapê do Norte foi apontada como primeira causa de insuficiência alimentar e nutricional destas comunidades. A transformação de uso da terra causou um intenso processo de desestruturação dos modelos de vida tradicional e do sistema de produção agroecológico que garantia uma alimentação diversificada e abundante. Esta situação levou as famílias a uma grande dependência monetária: a maioria dos alimentos consumidos atualmente é comprada no supermercados das vilas vizinhas.

O projeto

O contexto brasileiro relatado no documentário pretende oferecer um ponto de partida para refletir sobre a grande força dos movimentos de baixo para cima e sobre as populações que lutam contra os interesses econômicos de empresas e governos com democracias corruptas.

Joice e Antonio moram na comunidade de Linharinho, onde nasceram. Mas há mais de vinte anos eles lutam para conseguir seu lugar para morar. A aldeia foi invadida pela monocultura de eucalipto, que secou os rios, extinguiu os animais, envenenou a população e deu origem ao conflito. Aqui, junto com muitos outros, eles tentam resistir e curar uma terra que lhes pertence.

A segurança alimentar está ameaçada pela falta de um suprimento saudável de alimentos. A agricultura sustentável e as tradições locais estão comprometidas em nome do lucro. Os meios de subsistência dos habitantes estão diminuindo rapidamente.

Joice e Antonio, com seus filhos, têm retomado uma terra dominada pelo eucalipto para construir sua casa e seu projeto agroecológico: um pequeno sistema de produção de café permacultural. Uma experimentação ecológica para produzir café - uma cultura histórica destas áreas tropicais - através de práticas sustentáveis de consociação, biofertilizantes, nutrição do solo e aumento da fertilidade, a fim de retornar à produção ecológica de um produto local.

Joice diz: "O objetivo da Agroecológica Agrícola é produzir, no médio prazo, café e outras plantas de agricultura familiar da mais alta qualidade, utilizando os recursos do território para uma qualidade alimentar saudável e sustentável".

A terra está pronta. Nos últimos meses, o solo foi preparado para acomodar cafeeiros, fornecendo matéria orgânica e evitando a erosão, a lavagem do solo e o combate à evapotranspiração. Uma produção completamente natural também garantirá maiores rendimentos do mercado.

Há enxadas e a temporada está chegando: Ajude Joice e Antonio para a primeira colheita! Apoie a causa e ajude a promover o direito à segurança alimentar!

Você pode apoiar o projeto com a contribuição e orçamento que você deseja.

Quem optar por apoiar este projeto, independentemente do valor doado, será incluído nos créditos com um grande agradecimento por contribuir para o sucesso do projeto.

O projeto é um desenvolvimento independente, quase totalmente autofinanciado!
Parte dos recursos captados em nosso apoio será usada para cobrir custos administrativos, cobertura de seguro para transporte e equipamento técnico e todas as outras despesas extraordinárias.

O apoio daqueles que acreditam que a informação independente é mais do que nunca um bom "investimento" é essencial

Apoie-nos e seremos gratos a você,

Obrigado a todos!

Se você tiver interesse e quiser aprofundar o tópico clique aqui

https://pt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quilombolas

http://www.hlrn.org/news.php?id=p2hoZw==#.Wt5KitNuZQI

https://kizoomba.wordpress.com/premio-funarte-de-teatro-miriam-muniz/comunidade-quilombola-de-linharinho-es/

https://ejatlas.org/conflict/eucalyptus-plantations-aracruz-celulose-brazil

 

Quem somos?

Simone Tinelli

Cooperante de formaçã, estudou desenvolvimento sustentável do território e permacultura com foco em projetos de desenvolvimento rural relacionados à agricultura familiar.
Ele acompanha a luta dos quilombolas e o reconhecimento de suas terras desde 2011. Nos últimos anos, ele colaborou com a ONG brasileira FASE para estudar programas de desenvolvimento territorial sustentáveis destinados a promover técnicas agroecológicas no cultivo em pequena escala e reconhecimento cultural das tradições locais.

Andrea Corrao

Trabalhou no mundo da produção de vídeo, está se aproximando do mundo das ONGs e da cooperação internacional pela primeira vez, com um crescente interesse na permacultura, as práticas de vida sustentável e o conhecimento do racismo ambiental e a dinâmica da exploração de comunidades indígenas em todo o mundo.

TO READ / PER LEGGERE IN ITALIANO / LER EM PORTUGUÊS
SCROLL DOWN / SCORRI GIU' / ROLAR PARA BAIXO

https://www.facebook.com/direitosdepapel/
https://www.instagram.com/direitosdepapel/
 
ENG
Supporting this project you can achieve two goals in a single act: the production of a video-documentary and the start-up of a coffee plantation in the quilombola community of Linharinho. And maybe in a very close future you could receive the best coffee you have ever invested in! 
Obrigado for your help.
In the Sapê do Norte, in the state of Espírito Santo, Brazil, the local people of Quilombolas - descendants of black slaves - are marginalized and eradicated, along with the local flora, by corporations of paper and oil, a scenario sadly common to many other areas on the planet where monoculture is dominant over local cultures, ecosystems and biodiversity.
The 'Retomadas', the Quilombola re-appropriations, are formed by people living in the quilombo (place of refuge) and that are surrounded by eucalyptus and sugar cane monocultures and oil stations. In these areas, communities work to reconvert soil, increasing biodiversity, which has suffered degradation, deforestation and pollution for over fifty years; trying to produce healthy, sustainable food that will ensure their survival in their native lands.
In the '70s, the Norwegian corporation Aracruz, now a brazilian company with the name of Fibria - world's first producer of cellulose and paper - illegally bought vast areas of tropical forest from the dictatorship to promote the idea of development based on large-scale monoculture. Eucalyptus, native of Australia, thanks to the warm climate, in Brazil reaches 25m in only six years. Along with soy and sugar cane, is one of the great crops of brazilian agribusiness, which takes millions of hectares of ancient land and historically populated by indigenous peoples and Quilombolas, as in the case of Sapê do Norte region.
There are 1,200 families living in the region (12,000 in the '70s), but life in this green desert of plants is difficult. The Quilombola people lived on subsistence: they hunted, fished, harvested fruit and medicines and farmed the land in one of the most fertile areas of the planet. But today nothing grows among eucalyptus trees. Eucalyptus monoculture makes the soil poor, drains watercourses and contaminates with pesticides and herbicides used in plantations destroying biodiversity.
The Brazilian Constitution declares that these lands belong to traditional peoples and that it's duty of the state to recognize their property, giving priority and guaranteeing subsistence activities. The case of the illegal presence of Fibria in Quilombola territory represents yet another case of corruption and failure of public policies in Brazil.
Food traditions are getting lost. The nutritional values of a diversified food and the result of the ground work as well. Along with dendê oil, cassava manioc plant and the simple daily rice and beans, the cultivation of these foods is in danger. Today, the presence of eucalyptus monoculture in the lands of Sapê do Norte is identified as the main cause of food and nutrition insecurity in these communities. The processing of land use has caused an intense process of deconstruction of traditional ways of life and of agri-ecological production system that guaranteed a diversified and abundant diet. This situation has led to a high degree of monetary dependence among households: most of food currently consumed is bought in stores in neighbouring cities.

The Project
The brazilian background reported in the documentary aims to offer a starting point for reflecting on the great strength of bottom-up movements and on populations that fight against economic interests of corporations and governments with corrupt democracies.
Joice and Antonio live in the community of Linharinho, where they were born. But for over twenty years they have been struggling to have their place to live. The village was invaded by monoculture of eucalyptus, which dried rivers, extinct animals, poisoned people and led the conflict. Here, along with many others, they try to resist and heal a land that belongs to them.
Food security is threatened by the lack of a healthy food supply. Sustainable agriculture and local traditions are being compromised in the name of profit. The livelihoods of the inhabitants are rapidly decreasing. 
Joice and Antonio, with their children, have 'retomado' (taken back) a land dominated by eucalyptus to build their home and their agri-ecological project: a small permacultural coffee productive system. An ecological experimentation to produce coffee - a historical culture of tropical areas - through sustainable practices of consociation, biofertilizers, soil nutrition and increase of soil fertility, in order to have a return to an ecological production of a local product.
Joice says: -"he "Agricoltura Agroecológica goal is to produce, in the medium term, coffee and other plants from family agriculture of the highest quality using land resources for a healthy and sustainable food quality"
The earth is ready. In recent months, the soil has been prepared to accommodate coffee plants, providing organic matter and preventing erosion, soil runoff and combating evapotranspiration. Completely natural production will also ensure higher market yields.
There are hoes and the season is coming up: Help Joice and Antonio for their first harvest! Support the cause and help promote the right to food security!

Who we are?
Simone Tinelli
Cooperation worker, he studied sustainable territorial development and permaculture focusing on rural development projects related to family farming.He's been following the Quilombolas struggle and the recognition of their lands since 2011. In recent years he collaborated with the brazilian NGO FASE to study sustainable territorial development programs aimed at promoting agriecological techniques in small-scale cultivation and cultural recognition of local traditions.
Andrea Corrao
He has worked in video editing and production field, he approaches for the first time the world of NGOs and international cooperation, with an increasing interest in permaculture, sustainable living practices and knowledge of situations of environmental racism and exploitation dynamics of indigenous communities around the world.
 
 
ITACAFFÈ SOSTENIBILE NELLE PIANTAGIONI DI EUCALIPTOAiuta la comunità Quilombola che soffre di insicurezza alimentare a causa dell'industria della carta.  Sostenendo questo progetto contribuirai a due obiettivi con un solo gesto: verrà prodotto un video-documentario sulla situazione drammatica delle comunità brasiliane espropriate delle proprie terre e verrà avviata una piantagione di caffè nella comunità quilombola di Linharinho. E forse in un futuro molto vicino potresti ricevere anche il miglior caffè in cui tu abbia mai investito!Obrigado per il tuo aiuto!Nel Brasile dei disordini socio-politici e delle continue pressioni che minacciano l’Amazzonia, molte persone e foreste native hanno dovuto lasciare il posto alla monocoltura di eucalipto.Perchè? Per produrre la cellulosa, materia prima della carta che utilizziamo tutti i giorni: fogli, carta igienica, riviste, carta fotografica.Dove? Nel Sapê do Norte, nello stato di Espírito Santo, in Brasile, dove le popolazioni locali dei Quilombola sono emarginate ed estirpate, insieme alla flora locale, dalle multinazionali della carta e del petrolio; uno scenario purtroppo comune a molte altre zone del pianeta dove la monocultura si impone prepotentemente su culture, ecosistemi e biodiversità locali.Le retomadas, le riappropriazioni Quilombola, sono formate da persone che vivono nel quilombo (luogo di rifugio) e che sono circondate dalle monocolture di eucalipto e canna da zucchero e dalle stazioni petrolifere. In queste aree, le comunità lavorano per la riconversione del suolo, aumentando la biodiversità che da oltre cinquant’anni soffre degradazione, deforestazione e inquinamento. Cercando di produrre un cibo sano, sostenibile e che ne garantisca la sopravvivenza nelle loro terre native.Negli anni ‘70 la multinazionale norvegese Aracruz, ora impresa brasiliana col nome di Fibria - prima produttrice mondiale di cellulosa e carta, acquista illegalmente dalla dittatura vaste zone di foresta tropicale per promuovere l'idea di sviluppo basato sulla monocoltura in larga scala.Grazie al clima favorevole, in Brasile questa pianta raggiunge 25m in soli sei anni. L’eucalipto, insieme alla soia e alla canna da zucchero, è una delle grandi colture dell'agrobusiness brasiliano che si prende milioni di ettari di terre antiche e storicamente occupate da popolazioni indigene o discendenti di schiavi neri, i quilombola, come nel caso della regione del Sapê do Norte.Nella regione vivono 1.200 famiglie (erano 12.000 negli anni '70), ma la vita in questo deserto verde di piante è difficile. Le popolazioni quilombola vivevano di sussistenza: cacciavano, pescavano, raccoglievano i frutti e coltivavano la terra di una delle zone più fertili del pianeta. Ma oggi tra gli eucalipti non cresce niente. La monocoltura di eucalipto lascia il terreno povero, prosciuga i corsi d’acqua e inquina con i pesticidi ed erbicidi usati nelle piantagioni.La Costituzione dichiara che la terra appartiene alle popolazioni tradizionali e che è dovere dello stato riconoscerne la proprietà, dando precedenza e garantendo le attività di sussistenza. Il caso della presenza illegale della Fibria in territorio quilombola rappresenta l'ennesimo caso di corruzione e fallimento delle politiche pubbliche in Brasile.Le tradizioni alimentari stanno andando perse. I valori nutritivi di un cibo diversificato e frutto del lavoro della terra pure. Insieme all’olio di dendê, alla manioca e al semplice e quotidiano riso e fagioli la coltivazione di questi alimenti è in pericolo. Oggi la presenza della monocoltura di eucalipto nelle terre del Sapê do Norte è individuata come prima causa di insicurezza alimentare e nutrizionale di tali comunità. La trasformazione d’uso della terra ha causato un intenso processo di destrutturazione dei modi di vita tradizionali e del sistema di produzione agroecologico che garantiva un’alimentazione diversificata e abbondante. Questa situazione ha portato le famiglie ad una grande dipendenza monetaria: la maggior parte degli alimenti consumati attualmente viene comprata nei supermercati delle città vicine.il ProgettoIl contesto brasiliano riportato nel documentario intende offrire un punto di partenza per riflettere sulla grande forza dei movimenti dal basso verso l'alto e sulle popolazioni che lottano contro gli interessi economici delle imprese e dei governi con democrazie corrotte.Joice e Antonio vivono nella comunità di Linharinho, dove sono nati. Ma per oltre vent'anni hanno lottato per avere il loro posto dove vivere. Il villaggio è stato invaso dalla monocoltura di eucalipto, che ha prosciugato fiumi, estinto animali, avvelenato la popolazione e innescato il conflitto. Qui, insieme a molti altri, cercano di resistere e guarire una terra che appartiene a loro.   La sicurezza alimentare è minacciata dalla mancanza di un approvvigionamento alimentare sano. L'agricoltura sostenibile e le tradizioni locali vengono compromesse in nome del profitto. I mezzi di sussistenza degli abitanti stanno rapidamente diminuendo. Joice e Antonio, con i loro figli, hanno "retomado" (ripreso, rioccupato) una terra dominata dall'eucalipto per costruire la loro casa e il loro progetto agro-ecologico: un piccolo sistema produttivo permaculturale di caffè. Una sperimentazione ecologica per produrre caffè -coltura storica di queste aree tropicali - attraverso pratiche sostenibili di consociazione, biofertilizzanti, nutrimento del suolo e aumento della fertilità, al fine di tornare alla produzione ecologica di un prodotto locale.Joice dice: "L'obiettivo di Agricoltura Agroecológica è quello di produrre, nel medio termine, caffè e altre piante da agricoltura familiare di altissima qualità utilizzando le risorse del territorio per una qualità alimentare sana e sostenibile".La terra è pronta. Negli ultimi mesi, il suolo è stato preparato per accogliere le piante di caffè, fornendo materia organica e prevenendo l'erosione, il dilavamento del suolo e combattendo contro l'evapotraspirazione. Una produzione completamente naturale garantirà anche rese di mercato più elevate.Ci sono le zappe e la stagione sta arrivando: Aiuta Joice e Antonio per il loro primo raccolto! Sostieni la causa e aiuta a promuovere il diritto alla sicurezza alimentare!Puoi sostenere il progetto con il contributo e il budget che desideri.Chiunque scelga di sostenere questo progetto, indipendentemente dall'importo donato, sarà incluso nei crediti con un grande ringraziamento per aver contribuito al successo del progetto.Il progetto è uno sviluppo indipendente, quasi totalmente autofinanziato!Una parte dei fondi raccolti a nostro sostegno sarà utilizzata per coprire i costi amministrativi, la copertura assicurativa per i trasporti e le attrezzature tecniche e tutte le altre spese straordinarie.Il sostegno di coloro che credono che l'informazione indipendente sia oggi più che mai un buon "investimento" è fondamentaleAppoggiaci e te ne saremo grati,Grazie a tutti!Se ti interessa e vuoi approfondire l'argomento clicca qui:https://it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quilombohttp://www.hlrn.org/news.php?id=p2hoZw==#.Wt5KitNuZQIhttps://ejatlas.org/conflict/eucalyptus-plantations-aracruz-celulose-brazil Chi siamo?Simone TinelliCooperante di formazione, ha studiato sviluppo sostenibile del territorio e permacultura focalizzandosi in progetti di sviluppo rurale legati all’agricoltura familiare. Segue la lotta dei Quilombola e il riconoscimento delle loro terre dal 2011. In questi anni ha collaborato con la ONG brasiliana FASE sullo studio di programmi di sviluppo territoriale sostenibile volti a promuovere pratiche agroecologiche nelle coltivazioni di piccola scala e al riconoscimento culturale delle tradizioni locali.Andrea CorraoHa lavorato nel mondo della produzione video, si avvicina per la prima volta al mondo delle ONG e della cooperazione internazionale, con un interesse sempre più crescente per la permacultura, le pratiche del vivere sostenibile e la conoscenza delle situazioni di razzismo ambientale e di dinamiche di sfruttamento delle comunità autoctone in giro per il mondo. BRANo Brasil dos protestos sociopolíticos e das contínuas pressões que ameaçam a Amazônia, muitas pessoas e florestas tiveram que deixar o passo para a monocultura de eucalipto.Porque? Para produzir celulose, a matéria-prima do papel que utilizamos cada dia: folhas, papel higiênico, magazines, papel fotográfico.No Sapê do Norte, no estado do Espírito Santo, onde as populações locais Quilombolas são continuamente marginalizadas e extirpadas, junto com a flora local, pelas multinacionais de papel e petróleo; um cenário infelizmente comum em várias regiões do planeta onde a monocultura se impõe fortemente sobre culturas, ecossistemas e biodiversidade locais.A retomada quilombola, é formada por pessoas que vivem no quilombo ( lugar de refugio), e que estão cercados pelo monocultivo de eucalipto(celulose), cana de açúcar,complexo petroleiro, empresas que oprime todas comunidades que aqui existem, muitas famílias já foram embora de várias localidades, temos muitas escassez de água, as retomadas quilombolas são áreas que estão sendo retomadas pelos quilombolas e nestas áreas vem sendo feito vários trabalhos de reconversão de solo, solo estes que por mais de 50 anos sofreram com a degradação, desmatamentos, contaminação do solo, dentre outros, enumeras famílias tem trabalhado para conseguir tirar alimentos de boa qualidade e sustentável dessas áreas para sobreviverem.Nos anos 70, em tempos de governo ditatorial, a multinacional norueguêsa Aracruz - agora empresa brasileira com o nome de Fibria, primeira produtora mundial de celulose e papel - compra ilegalmente da ditadura várias áreas de floresta nativa para promover a ideia de desenvolvimento baseada na monocultura em grande escala.Graças ao clima favorável, no Brasil esta planta atinge 25m em apenas seis anos. O eucalipto, junto com a soja e a cana de açúcar, é um dos maiores cultivos do agronegócio brasileiro, tomando milhões de hectares de terras antigas e historicamente ocupadas por populações indígenas ou quilombolas, como no caso da região do Sapê do Norte.Na região  moram 1.200 famílias (12.000 nos anos ‘70), mas a vida nesse deserto verde de plantas é difícil. As populações quilombolas viviam de subsistência: elas caçavam, pescavam, recolhiam os frutos e cultivavam a terra de uma das áreas mais férteis do planeta. Mas hoje em dia nada cresce entre os eucaliptos. Este monocultivo deixa o solo pobre, seca os rios e polui com pesticidas e herbicidas usados nas plantações.A Constituição declara que a terra pertence às populações tradicionais e que é dever do Estado reconhecer a propriedade, favorecendo e garantindo as atividades de subsistência. O caso da presença ilegal da Fibria em território quilombola representa mais um caso de corrupção e falha das políticas públicas no Brasil.As tradições alimentares estão se perdendo. Os valores nutritivos de uma comida diversificada e fruto do trabalho da terra também. Junto com o óleo de dendê, a mandioca e o cotidiano arroz e feijão, o cultivo destes alimentos está em perigo. Hoje a presença do monocultura de eucalipto nas terras do Sapê do Norte foi apontada como primeira causa de insuficiência alimentar e nutricional destas comunidades. A transformação de uso da terra causou um intenso processo de desestruturação dos modelos de vida tradicional e do sistema de produção agroecológico que garantia uma alimentação diversificada e abundante. Esta situação levou as famílias a uma grande dependência monetária: a maioria dos alimentos consumidos atualmente é comprada no supermercados das vilas vizinhas.O projetoO contexto brasileiro relatado no documentário pretende oferecer um ponto de partida para refletir sobre a grande força dos movimentos de baixo para cima e sobre as populações que lutam contra os interesses econômicos de empresas e governos com democracias corruptas.Joice e Antonio moram na comunidade de Linharinho, onde nasceram. Mas há mais de vinte anos eles lutam para conseguir seu lugar para morar. A aldeia foi invadida pela monocultura de eucalipto, que secou os rios, extinguiu os animais, envenenou a população e deu origem ao conflito. Aqui, junto com muitos outros, eles tentam resistir e curar uma terra que lhes pertence.A segurança alimentar está ameaçada pela falta de um suprimento saudável de alimentos. A agricultura sustentável e as tradições locais estão comprometidas em nome do lucro. Os meios de subsistência dos habitantes estão diminuindo rapidamente.Joice e Antonio, com seus filhos, têm retomado uma terra dominada pelo eucalipto para construir sua casa e seu projeto agroecológico: um pequeno sistema de produção de café permacultural. Uma experimentação ecológica para produzir café - uma cultura histórica destas áreas tropicais - através de práticas sustentáveis de consociação, biofertilizantes, nutrição do solo e aumento da fertilidade, a fim de retornar à produção ecológica de um produto local.Joice diz: "O objetivo da Agroecológica Agrícola é produzir, no médio prazo, café e outras plantas de agricultura familiar da mais alta qualidade, utilizando os recursos do território para uma qualidade alimentar saudável e sustentável".A terra está pronta. Nos últimos meses, o solo foi preparado para acomodar cafeeiros, fornecendo matéria orgânica e evitando a erosão, a lavagem do solo e o combate à evapotranspiração. Uma produção completamente natural também garantirá maiores rendimentos do mercado.Há enxadas e a temporada está chegando: Ajude Joice e Antonio para a primeira colheita! Apoie a causa e ajude a promover o direito à segurança alimentar!Você pode apoiar o projeto com a contribuição e orçamento que você deseja.Quem optar por apoiar este projeto, independentemente do valor doado, será incluído nos créditos com um grande agradecimento por contribuir para o sucesso do projeto.O projeto é um desenvolvimento independente, quase totalmente autofinanciado!Parte dos recursos captados em nosso apoio será usada para cobrir custos administrativos, cobertura de seguro para transporte e equipamento técnico e todas as outras despesas extraordinárias.O apoio daqueles que acreditam que a informação independente é mais do que nunca um bom "investimento" é essencialApoie-nos e seremos gratos a você,Obrigado a todos!Se você tiver interesse e quiser aprofundar o tópico clique aquihttps://pt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quilombolashttp://www.hlrn.org/news.php?id=p2hoZw==#.Wt5KitNuZQIhttps://kizoomba.wordpress.com/premio-funarte-de-teatro-miriam-muniz/comunidade-quilombola-de-linharinho-es/https://ejatlas.org/conflict/eucalyptus-plantations-aracruz-celulose-brazil Quem somos?Simone TinelliCooperante de formaçã, estudou desenvolvimento sustentável do território e permacultura com foco em projetos de desenvolvimento rural relacionados à agricultura familiar.Ele acompanha a luta dos quilombolas e o reconhecimento de suas terras desde 2011. Nos últimos anos, ele colaborou com a ONG brasileira FASE para estudar programas de desenvolvimento territorial sustentáveis destinados a promover técnicas agroecológicas no cultivo em pequena escala e reconhecimento cultural das tradições locais.Andrea CorraoTrabalhou no mundo da produção de vídeo, está se aproximando do mundo das ONGs e da cooperação internacional pela primeira vez, com um crescente interesse na permacultura, as práticas de vida sustentável e o conhecimento do racismo ambiental e a dinâmica da exploração de comunidades indígenas em todo o mundo.

story:
"Pleistocene Park is a starting point. If you want to create an ecosystem big enough to have an impact on the climate, you need people to understand that they have a role to play."  -  New York Times

A father and son’s quixotic quest to bring back a lost ecosystem—and save the world.'"      -Science Magazine

“If Nikita has his way, Pleistocene Park will spread across Arctic Siberia and into North America, helping to slow the thawing of the Arctic permafrost.” - The Atlantic

From Nikita Zimov, director of the Pleistocene Park.

Arctic permafrost is melting. It will trigger catastrophic global warming. We’re creating a northern Serengeti to stop that from happening.

Pleistocene Park is a proof of concept, a public demonstration, a landscape scale art project and a philosophy of rational co-existence between humans and nature.

Here in the most remote corner of Siberia my father, Sergey Zimov, and I are reviving the ice age “Mammoth Steppe” ecosystem. Re-wilding this vast area of the Arctic will not only create a northern Serengeti, but most importantly, today, is a vital tool to mitigate global climate change. As climate warms, permafrost here in the Arctic is starting to melt. It will soon unlock huge carbon stocks and trigger a catastrophic global warming feedback loop. Natural grasslands, maintained by numerous grazing animals, have the capacity to both slow climate warming and prevent permafrost from melting.

Me, Nikita Zimov, and my father, Sergey Zimov

We’ve already starting transforming the land, with our real world prototype.

For the past 20 years my family has spent a big portion of our time and all available finances to create Pleistocene Park. Currently we have over 90 large herbivores in the Park, including cold adapted Yakutian horses, moose, musk ox, reindeer, wisent, yaks and sheeps. These animals have shown that it is possible to transform ecosystems and reestablish high productivity grasslands by reintroducing large herbivores. 

 We have fenced 20 square kilometers of land, built infrastructure and installed monitoring equipment. To bring animals to the Park we have mounted extreme expeditions ourselves. We traveled by small boat through the Arctic Ocean to Wrangel Island and from the Mongolian border with a 4x4 military transport truck, driving thousands of kilometers on frozen rivers through roadless wilderness.

Musk ox at the Pleistocene Park

To stand a chance of mitigating global warming on a much bigger scale we need your help to take the park to the next level!

However, for mitigating global warming, the size of the Park is not enough. This crowdfunding campaign is one of our first attempts to invite other people to participate in our project and an important step towards turning the modern Arctic into a northern Serengeti and stop permafrost degradation on a big scale.

Join us in creating a world where we harness nature to protect the planet we live on.

Last year we ran a crowdfunding campaign to bring yaks and bison to Pleistocene Park.  With the help of 750 backers we successfully raised $106,000. In June we traveled more than 6000 miles by truck and river barge, through some of the most remote territory on earth, to transport 10 yaks to their new home.  We spent the fall and winter looking for bison. The best bison we found is a herd owned by a Native American tribe in Alaska. We bought 12 baby bison there. Dr Michelle Oakley (famous from the National Geographic show “Yukon Vet”) performed the veterinary testing necessary for export.

Quarantine requirements will be over and the bison will be ready to travel early next month.  We are chartering a Canadian cargo plane to fly from Fairbanks Alaska across the Bering Straits to Pleistocene Park in Siberia.   Chartering the plane alone costs $130,000 making this the most expensive expedition we have ever undertaken to bring animals to Pleistocene Park.  We are running this, our second crowdfunding campaign, to raise money to pay for this airplane to carry our bison to Pleistocene Park.

Our 12 baby bison are in Alaska, waiting to travel to the Pleistocene Park.  Please support this campaign and let bison come back to Siberian Arctic for the first time in 10,000 years.

Location of the Pleistocene Park

Selected Media reports about Pleistocene Park:

Here is a list of media which wrote or filmed about Pleistocene Park. The list is not complete, so please excuse us if something is missing.

  • The Atlantic Magazine/New York Times/Vice on HBO /National Geographic/Россия24 (Russia24 News)/НТВ/ARTE/BBC Radio/BBC News/New Yorker/New York Times/Science Magazine 1/Science Magazine 2/Science Magazine 3/NBC/ARD (1st German Television)/WDR/Scientific American/New Scientist/Business Insider/The Telegraph/Wired/Independent/Geocurrents/Live Science/How It Works/Der Spiegel/Siberian Times/Mysterious Universe/Daily Galaxy/Aljazeera/La Republica/24Heures/Ottawa Life/ABC/Stanford Magazine/TED Talk 1/TED Talk 2

An Artists rendering of what the mammoth steppe looked like

 

What is Pleistocene Park reviving? 

During the last Ice Age, steppes with millions of mammoths, bison, horses, reindeers, tigers, wolves and numerous other animals occupied vast landscapes, spanning from Spain to Canada and from the Arctic islands to China.

Being the world biggest biome, mammoth steppe was as productive as the modern African savannah. These remains we collected on 1 hectare of eroded permafrost. Almost 30 big herbivores were roaming on each square kilometer of these endless pastures.

These vast herds maintained their pastures by cycling nutrients, promoting grass and herb growth, and dramatically increasing the productivity of the pastures. Looking at the modern low productive vegetation and few animals in the Arctic, it is hardly possible for people to imagine, such animal densities could exist in this place in the past. With the end the last Ice Age, the first humans came to this place and quickly killed most animals, driving many species extinct, and destroying the fragile symbiosis between plants and animals. Without herbivores, grasses could not compete with moss or shrubs. A few centuries later this ecosystem was gone. Now, for the first time in 10,000 years, we are bringing together animals which once roamed this place. Unfortunately not all the species made it to modern times, but we are trying to collect an animal assemblage which would restore the ecological function of the Mammoth Steppe.

These animals are roaming together for the first time in 10 thousand years

 

Melting Permafrost

The Arctic is rapidly getting warmer and permafrost is starting to thaw. On a local scale it means destruction of houses, roads and power lines. In addition, it means death to all modern Arctic ecosystems – the ground collapses, trees topple, canyons and depressions form, and Arctic rivers turn into mud flows with the destruction of fish populations.

However, the global impact of permafrost degradation is even greater. Permafrost contains twice as much carbon as the earth’s atmosphere. When it thaws microbes transform this organic material into carbon dioxide and methane, creating a massive source of greenhouse gases, thus amplifying global warming to an even greater extent.

Melting permafrost at Duvanii Yar. On the right you can see 30,000 year old roots of grass that will decompose and contribute to global warming.

 

Methane bubbles from degrading permafrost trapped under ice (left). My father lighting methane on fire (right)

 

 How can restoring a lost Ice Age ecosystem mitigate global warming?

There are several mechanisms by which great herds of herbivores, once again roaming the Arctic, can cool the climate and reduce the amount of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere.

  • Animals will prevent permafrost from melting. To make permafrost colder, all that is needed is to remove heat insulating snow cover, and expose the ground to the extreme negative temperatures of the Arctic. In the steppe ecosystems, animal density is so high that animals looking for forage trample all the snow in the pastures several times per winter. This compacts the snow, massively reducing its heat insulating abilities.

This shows how animals trample snow and reduce its insulating value, making the soil colder

  • Grasses through the process of photosynthesis absorb carbon dioxide (strong greenhouse gas) from the atmosphere and preserve it in the form of roots. Cold Arctic soils assure that decomposition is low and roots do not decay for decades, centuries, or millennia. This creates a small but sustainable mechanism to partially absorb human emissions of greenhouse gases. The size of this is of course much smaller than our current human impact, but it is at least a step in the right direction.
  • Vast steppes allow direct cooling of the climate by increasing surface reflectance. Grasslands are much lighter in color than shrublands and forests. Therefore, they reflect a greater portion of direct sunlight energy back into space without transforming it into heat (albedo effect). This effect is especially pronounced in the early spring, when the sun is already active in the Arctic – dark forests absorb heat, while steppes are covered with snow and remain white. This is also why the Arctic Ocean is warming as the Polar ice caps melt.

Difference in colour between grasslands and forest in different seasons.

 

These animated slides showing ecological effects of promoting steppes, was kindly provided by Revive & Restore, designed by Ben J. Novak

 

Why is Pleistocene Park asking for crowdfunding help? 

Up to this date, Pleistocene Park was an experiment created mostly from the labor and funds of my father, my family and me, which we obtained from running the remote Arctic research station.

However, if we want to create a tool that will help us mitigate global warming, we have to take the Park to a totally different level. For that we need other people to participate in our project. For this purpose we have established the Pleistocene Park Foundation, Inc, which is a non-profit based in Pennsylvania, USA (received 501c3 status in December, 2017), to facilitate the development and implementation the Pleistocene Park ideas across the world. The Foundation is also charged with the goal to raise funds to the science and logistics behind this promising idea.

Using our tank to build the fence at Pleistocene Park.

What we will do: 

The specific scope of this campaign is to bring herds of bison to Pleistocene Park in the spring of 2018. We already bought twelve one-year-old American plains bison from a Native American Village in Alaska. Animals has already passed all veterinary tests and now preserved in the quarantine. From there animals will be placed into the individual  crates, loaded on the truck and taken to the international airport of Fairbanks. From there we will charter the airplane to fly to the easternmost city of Anadyr’ in Russia, where animals would clear customs and continue on the same plane to the home town of the Pleistocene Park – Cherskii. There another truck would take bison to the park. Bison was a keystone specie in the mammoth steppe ecosystem in the past and we expect it to take dominant role in the modern high productive steppes as well.

The bison transport route from Alaska to the Pleistocene Park

How will the crowdfunding money be spent? 

Our goal is to raise 98,000 dollars. This money would be added to the money left from our first crowdfunding campaign and personal fund of the Pleistocene Park to pay for the following item:

  • Purchase of 12 bison from the Native tribe of Stevens Village;
  • Construction of crates
  • Veterinary expenses in the United States
  • Truck rental for animal transportation
  • Custom fees
  • Airplane rental with all expenses related to the flight both within USA and Russia.
  • Miscellaneous trip expenses, including 1-3 people travelling with the animals, 
  • Expense of manufacturing and delivery of crowdfunding campaign rewards 
  • Taxes, bank and legal fees

 

Push goals and long-term development plans

We set the campaign goal to flexible. Bison is the key animal for the Pleistocene Park and we are intending to get animals to the park even if that would lead to complicated financial situation for the Park

  • $60,000 is the absolute minimum to make this happen.  It will cover around half of the airfare.  This will create financial hardship for me but we will survive.  
  • $98,000 will cover most charter airplane expenses and leave Pleistocene Park on a more even keel moving forward.  
  • $200,000 We will also organize transportion of additional animals to the Pleistocene park from within Russia, including reindeer, horses, elk, boars. 
  • $600,000 We will launch an expedition to bring a herd of at least 20 musk ox. We will explore other options of Arctic adapted animals and bring them. We will improve infrastructure to support the additional animals. Within 2-3 years we would be able to seriously transform the land within current fences.
  • $1,000,000 We will extend the Pleistocene Park in every direction. There will be more land, more animals introduced, more people participating in our project.
  • $3,000,000 We will complete the ecosystem by introducing predators. We will have enough prey to maintain sustainable population of predators in the Park: wolves and potentially Amur tigers.
  • $10,000,000 + We will transport 1000+ bison by ship to the Pleistocene Park region. This is the scale that will be necessary to begin fully implementing restoration of the high productive steppes and stabilize melting permafrost on a large scale.
  • $1 billion  is the rough estimate of the total price for our civilization to restore real wild nature on a continental scale and have actual impact on climate. While not a small amount of money it is one of the largest environmental impacts possible for a sum well within the budget of a wealthy individual or a corporation. Large infrastructure projects like bridges, dams or clean energy programs are in this range or larger.

 

Risks and challenges

Transportation of Animals to the Pleistocene Park:

We have prepared a logistical plan which will allow safe and comfortable trip for the animals. This is our 8th expedition to bring animals to Pleistocene Park. Some of these trips have been longer and more complicated and all have been successful.

All animals in this trip will be transported in individual stalls. They will have enough space to stand up and lay down for rest. The design of the containers will allow animals to have access to enough fresh air, water and forage. The route and timing of the expedition will be planned to minimize time of animals spent in travel.

Adaptation of Animals in the Pleistocene Park.

In order to keep our crowdfunding budget reasonable we did not include any of the expenses for the adaptation of the animals in their first year in the Park. However I have already committed to invest my personal resources in proper animal care. This will include:

- Full time salary for the ranger with veterinary education;
- Transportation of forage to the Park to supply animals in the winter period;
-- Construction of shelter/shelters to allow animals to adapt to the cold in the autumn/winter period.
story_txt:
"Pleistocene Park is a starting point. If you want to create an ecosystem big enough to have an impact on the climate, you need people to understand that they have a role to play."  -  New York TimesA father and son’s quixotic quest to bring back a lost ecosystem—and save the world.'"      -Science Magazine“If Nikita has his way, Pleistocene Park will spread across Arctic Siberia and into North America, helping to slow the thawing of the Arctic permafrost.” - The AtlanticFrom Nikita Zimov, director of the Pleistocene Park.Arctic permafrost is melting. It will trigger catastrophic global warming. We’re creating a northern Serengeti to stop that from happening.Pleistocene Park is a proof of concept, a public demonstration, a landscape scale art project and a philosophy of rational co-existence between humans and nature.Here in the most remote corner of Siberia my father, Sergey Zimov, and I are reviving the ice age “Mammoth Steppe” ecosystem. Re-wilding this vast area of the Arctic will not only create a northern Serengeti, but most importantly, today, is a vital tool to mitigate global climate change. As climate warms, permafrost here in the Arctic is starting to melt. It will soon unlock huge carbon stocks and trigger a catastrophic global warming feedback loop. Natural grasslands, maintained by numerous grazing animals, have the capacity to both slow climate warming and prevent permafrost from melting.Me, Nikita Zimov, and my father, Sergey ZimovWe’ve already starting transforming the land, with our real world prototype.For the past 20 years my family has spent a big portion of our time and all available finances to create Pleistocene Park. Currently we have over 90 large herbivores in the Park, including cold adapted Yakutian horses, moose, musk ox, reindeer, wisent, yaks and sheeps. These animals have shown that it is possible to transform ecosystems and reestablish high productivity grasslands by reintroducing large herbivores.  We have fenced 20 square kilometers of land, built infrastructure and installed monitoring equipment. To bring animals to the Park we have mounted extreme expeditions ourselves. We traveled by small boat through the Arctic Ocean to Wrangel Island and from the Mongolian border with a 4x4 military transport truck, driving thousands of kilometers on frozen rivers through roadless wilderness.Musk ox at the Pleistocene ParkTo stand a chance of mitigating global warming on a much bigger scale we need your help to take the park to the next level!However, for mitigating global warming, the size of the Park is not enough. This crowdfunding campaign is one of our first attempts to invite other people to participate in our project and an important step towards turning the modern Arctic into a northern Serengeti and stop permafrost degradation on a big scale.Join us in creating a world where we harness nature to protect the planet we live on. Last year we ran a crowdfunding campaign to bring yaks and bison to Pleistocene Park.  With the help of 750 backers we successfully raised $106,000. In June we traveled more than 6000 miles by truck and river barge, through some of the most remote territory on earth, to transport 10 yaks to their new home.  We spent the fall and winter looking for bison. The best bison we found is a herd owned by a Native American tribe in Alaska. We bought 12 baby bison there. Dr Michelle Oakley (famous from the National Geographic show “Yukon Vet”) performed the veterinary testing necessary for export.Quarantine requirements will be over and the bison will be ready to travel early next month.  We are chartering a Canadian cargo plane to fly from Fairbanks Alaska across the Bering Straits to Pleistocene Park in Siberia.   Chartering the plane alone costs $130,000 making this the most expensive expedition we have ever undertaken to bring animals to Pleistocene Park.  We are running this, our second crowdfunding campaign, to raise money to pay for this airplane to carry our bison to Pleistocene Park.Our 12 baby bison are in Alaska, waiting to travel to the Pleistocene Park.  Please support this campaign and let bison come back to Siberian Arctic for the first time in 10,000 years.Location of the Pleistocene ParkSelected Media reports about Pleistocene Park:Here is a list of media which wrote or filmed about Pleistocene Park. The list is not complete, so please excuse us if something is missing.
The Atlantic Magazine/New York Times/Vice on HBO /National Geographic/Россия24 (Russia24 News)/НТВ/ARTE/BBC Radio/BBC News/New Yorker/New York Times/Science Magazine 1/Science Magazine 2/Science Magazine 3/NBC/ARD (1st German Television)/WDR/Scientific American/New Scientist/Business Insider/The Telegraph/Wired/Independent/Geocurrents/Live Science/How It Works/Der Spiegel/Siberian Times/Mysterious Universe/Daily Galaxy/Aljazeera/La Republica/24Heures/Ottawa Life/ABC/Stanford Magazine/TED Talk 1/TED Talk 2
An Artists rendering of what the mammoth steppe looked like What is Pleistocene Park reviving? During the last Ice Age, steppes with millions of mammoths, bison, horses, reindeers, tigers, wolves and numerous other animals occupied vast landscapes, spanning from Spain to Canada and from the Arctic islands to China.Being the world biggest biome, mammoth steppe was as productive as the modern African savannah. These remains we collected on 1 hectare of eroded permafrost. Almost 30 big herbivores were roaming on each square kilometer of these endless pastures. These vast herds maintained their pastures by cycling nutrients, promoting grass and herb growth, and dramatically increasing the productivity of the pastures. Looking at the modern low productive vegetation and few animals in the Arctic, it is hardly possible for people to imagine, such animal densities could exist in this place in the past. With the end the last Ice Age, the first humans came to this place and quickly killed most animals, driving many species extinct, and destroying the fragile symbiosis between plants and animals. Without herbivores, grasses could not compete with moss or shrubs. A few centuries later this ecosystem was gone. Now, for the first time in 10,000 years, we are bringing together animals which once roamed this place. Unfortunately not all the species made it to modern times, but we are trying to collect an animal assemblage which would restore the ecological function of the Mammoth Steppe.These animals are roaming together for the first time in 10 thousand years  Melting PermafrostThe Arctic is rapidly getting warmer and permafrost is starting to thaw. story:
We were so fortunate to meet many of you during our 2 years as the banana.van.adventures (@daniel.messick) . Throughout the 38 states and 4 countries (yes we went to Guatemala!!!) we were able to help many people either grow in their confidence to become nomads and were even able to work on people's homes thorough the country. Some we helped in the very beginning stages of projects, while in others we did repairs, but we were fortunate enough to do that all for free (or donations).

 

Since Rachel is now in school I will set up a stationary shop and, as much as I love working in the sun, there are rainy days. My goal is keeping production cost to a minimum so if we can offset building a shop by your donation then that would be amazing. 

 

Not only will this allow me to have more efficient build times, but also offer a place for people to come stay and me guide them on their own builds! Making the community safe is so key for them enjoying their time on the road exploring.

 

The shop size will be a 60 x 40 which is ample space for 3 units to be pulled in to stay out of the elements, still have my woodworking tools safely spaced out, and allow room for the expansion of metal working! The shop will also house; an office for me to stay organized, a kitchen with dinning for 10 (this room can also double as classroom for teaching), and 1.5 bathrooms. One bathroom will be ADA complaint because we want to make this opportunity open for as many as possible!

 

….

 

The cost of building materials has skyrocketed thus the extra need for assistance. As you can see in my draft, I’ve tried make it a fun way for you to know what you are buying! And I want to show my appreciation of your gift, so depending on the item you help to build,  you'll get a unique token of appreciation. 

 

Total

Units-Unit -$-Item-Reward

$4,000.00-400-$10.00-Board-Sticker

 

$625.00-25-$25.00-Hardware-Tshirt

$5,000.00-200-$25.00-Helping Hand-Tshirt

$1,500.00-30-$50.00-Detail Trim-Tank

$9,000.00-120-$75.00-Tin-Hat or Tshirt

$2,100.00-21-$100.00-Post-Long Sleeve

$3,250.00-13-$250.00-Truss-cutting board

$1,500.00-3-$500.00-Door /10' section-us flag cutting board

$4,000.00-4-$1,000.00-Garage Door

 

This is what is required to get the building up! The Classroom and bathrooms will be added in the future! Since we’ve lived Nomadically, we have solutions for bathrooms and kitchen for the time being, but the most important thing is getting the walls and roof up. 

 

Also to help keep cost down, we will not be adding concrete in the initial phase. Although concrete is wonderful for my unnecessary desire of a clean floor; it is harder on the joints, plus by keeping me more connected to the earth I can also plant a tree or two inside to help keep the air purer!

 

As a bonus, When we exceed the $20,000, I will do a random drawing of the contributors to  provide them with the average 200 hours required to do a build out for them* (the winner will be responsible for van, materials, transportation of unit, and any additions past the basic build). 

 

And then every $10k after the goal I will choose another winner!

 

At the $100K mark I will provide a complete turn key build to one lucky contributor!

…

There are numerous builders on the West Coast but on the East there aren’t as many and Someone with a desire to create a learning experience will be a great addition. I’m excited to have you on board of helping others achieve the dream of living nomadically. 

 

As in many ways it is very freeing to the mind to be able to reconnect with nature easier, to be able stop and enjoy the beauties around, to visit those distance friends and families.

 

Please share this opportunity with those around you.

 

If you would like more back story you can check out our page mocowo.com (its under construction too)
