story:
Protect the Great Plains:
No KXL, No Access

Keystone XL and Dakota Access aren't the first pipelines to threaten our land.

But we want to make sure they're the last.

Protecting the Great Plains is critical to protecting the earth, our people, our land, and our water. This campaign bridges our pipeline fights and brings power to the people on the front lines.

The Indigenous Environmental Network and Dakota Rural Action are teaming up to raise funds to support the on-going legal and grassroots fights against Keystone XL and Dakota Access. These two pipeline proposals threaten the Great Plains - and our planet, by deepening our reliance on dirty fossil fuels.


Donations to this campaign will go straight to Indigenous and non-native pipeline fighters in South Dakota: on-the-ground people, organizations, and tribes defending land and water in front of governmental agencies with help from lawyers and experts dedicated to stopping these dirty and dangerous extractive industries.

Why now?

We are building real power on the Plains, and we need your help to turn the tide. Over the past seven years, unlikely allies have come together to fight Keystone XL. We have forged friendships that now transcend just that fight, and we're now facing yet another pipeline proposal, Dakota Access. We have all stepped up again, together, to fight this new pipeline, but it is a lot of work and it costs a LOT of money, from legal fees to expert witnesses to training grassroots activists across the Plains.

It will take all of us - Indigenous, non-native, young, old, farmers, ranchers, urban, rural - to shift away from fossil fuels. We are fighting for our collective future, and we're asking you to join us to fight together.


What this campaign will help us fund:

  • Legal fees: We're lucky to have lawyers from across the country helping us in front of our local governmental agencies, but there is only so much they can do pro bono. If we're going to fight and win against the deep pockets of the Oil Industry, we need to help our legal teams get the support they need!
  • Expert witnesses: We need to bring in the experts who can talk about things like how badly pipelines have been built and the impacts of Keystone XL on our climate. Time and travel costs money, but having these experts on our side will make all the difference.
  • Grassroots activation: Big Oil has a lot of money for advertising and propaganda, but we have a lot of people who believe in a new energy future. Funds from this campaign will help on-the-ground organizers mobilize those people to take action and stand up to the companies who threaten our land.

Proposed Dakota Access Pipeline route across South Dakota

The People:

"I believe we have reached a critical point, as a community and nation, where we must decide either to continue our incessant hunger for petrochemicals or to alter our course. We can demand a much cleaner and sustainable energy future or continue to be trapped by our lust for fossil fuels and inability to change. I believe we have the desire and capacity to make the smart choice." - Tony Helland, Sioux Falls, South Dakota

“Pte Ospaye Spiritual Camp mission is stand in opposition to the Keystone XL Pipeline and the social evils that come with Big Oil. It is ground zero for the Lakota people fighting this pipeline as it would have to pass through this area first." Joye Braun, Bridger, South Dakota

”Benzene, a potent carcinogen, has increasingly become the most threatening of all environmental toxins...allowing one of the largest pipelines filled with the world’s dirtiest oil, under the most extreme pressure to funnel benzene and other toxins into South Dakota is a major public health threat. The lifeblood of South Dakota, the Missouri River, which supplies water to over 50% of the state must be protected." Cindy Meyers, Stuart, Nebraska

Proposed Keystone XL route across South Dakota

Our challenge:

We face an uphill battle.

Keystone XL has been an on-going fight in South Dakota for well over seven years. And the company proposing Dakota Access is already shipping pipe into South Dakota - they assume they'll get their permit, no questions asked.

We are in front of a political permitting body that's never denied a permit.

We are facing huge money and huge power in the Oil Industry.

But we are front and center in a global fight, and we are ready to take it to the next level. We wont stop fighting until Keystone XL and Dakota Access are denied in South Dakota. We wont stop until the Great Plains are protected, valued, and preserved for future generations!

YOU CAN HELP:

  • Donate now! We have some really great work happening here. Help us keep it going!
  • Share this campaign! The more we get this out, the more successful we'll be, and the more we'll win.
  • JOIN US: Sign up to help - email Sabrina (sabrina@dakotarural.org) or Dallas (goldtoothdallas@gmail.com) and we'll get you set up.
  • March with us in July: Join hundreds of pipeline fighters as we ride and march in to Pierre before the Keystone XL hearings. March with us: click here!

(Photo credit: Tory Stolen Photography)

Want to know more?

Indigenous Environmental Network: Facebook page and website

Dakota Rural Action: Facebook page and website

Check out our No KXL Dakota Coalition's Facebook page and website

story:
Let's get the MV Steve Irwin a new satellite communication system!

As most of you know I have been a Sea Shepherd volunteer for a few years now providing direct support to the ships and crew when they are down at our Southern Ocean Base in Melbourne (mainly organising food donations). Sea Shepherd's flagship, the MV Steve Irwin is currently docked here and getting repaired for the next ocean conservation campaign. Chatting with one of the captains the other day, I found out that the Steve is desperate to upgrade its marine satellite communication system. 

Why desperate? Because the current system is terribly outdated and communication is a key success factor on every campaign let alone a safety factor whilst out at sea. The current system's satellite phone and internet connection is very slow and often drops out completely...a problem when you need to get the latest photos and video footage of an encounter with poachers out quickly or when international media stations want to contact you for live interviews. The Steve's main role in the Sea Shepherd fleet is communication (and housing the helicopter). 

But apart from that the system is being used for secure communication and the tactical coordination between the Sea Shepherd ships (they are often not within radar range of each other to cover a wider area at sea and increase the chances to find poachers or the whaling fleet). The system is also being used for the latest weather updates (important in Antarctica where storms develop out of nowhere). But most importantly the system is used to contact the small boats when they are out and need to find their way back to the Steve before the weather changes or before they run out of fuel. 

Now, marine communication systems aren't cheap and the Steve is struggling right now to fund its emergency communication station (the part that radios in help before you jump on a liferaft). So the ship's official fundraising campaign is currently focussing on getting that sorted. 

However, the safety of the 40 or so crew onboard the Steve and the cause they are serving, protecting marine life for us and for future generations, is important to me. So, I have decided to run a private crowdfunding campaign. You are my crowd! Not a big crowd I must admit, and the amount we need is not small but I like a challenge and I like to believe that I am surrounded by people that care about the future of our oceans as much as I do. 

We have got some cool perks in exchange for your donations...including tickets to the amazing Wanderlust Yoga Festival! You can find more details below but let me thank you at this stage for reading this, for sharing this with people you think may be interested in contributing, and of course for your donation!!

For the oceans,

Andrea

Here is the plan: 

Fleet Broadband is not cheap...in fact, it will cost a whopping AUD 15,000, ouch! But operating it will only cost half of what the old system costs. So it's a good deal in the long run.  

Here is what I'm thinking...I did the same on a smaller scale 2 years ago (as some of you will remember) to raise funds for emergency equipment on another Sea Shepherd ship. With your help we can hopefully pull this one off as well. 

I will match what gets raised here up to AUD 1,000 and my employer will make an additional 4-digit contribution. I set the goal on this page to 5K so we have an achievable amount to raise. Fingers crossed though (and thumbs pressed, German style) that we can raise a 5-digit amount. The crew of the Steve will try to raise the remainder. 

Now, what's in it for you if you contribute to this fundraiser, apart from good ocean karma? Well, take a look at the perks listed on the side that the crew has put together. 

Also, the wonderful crew at Wanderlust have generoulsy donated 2 free tickets for their next 4-day Yoga Festival at Thredbo (Australia, 18 - 21 Feb 2016). I have been to their last festival and can tell you that it's sheer amazing so if I were you I would grab those tickets asap! They are currently selling for AUD 460 each and you can get them for just AUD 350, good ocean karma and all included! Check out the perks.

What else...I don't want anything for my birthday this month. Really, not even those little sweet sneaky presents on top of donations. Rather donate more please because the best present for me will be seeing that comms system getting installed on the ship! :)

I will keep you in the loop in terms of how much we ended up raising and let you know when the crew purchased and installed the new comms system.

And what, if we raise more than what we need, even the whole 15,000...wow, imagine! In that case I will post an update what additional items can be bought. Apart from that, the cost of fuel for the ship is about AUD 5,000 per day. Operation Icefish (more details further down) lasted for 110 days...

Now to the marine comms system

Voila, here is a hero shot of the object in need: 

It may not look like much but is a bit of a communication powerhouse. This is the FleetBroadband FB 500 that will hopefully replace the old VSAT unit. 

The Inmarsat FleetBroadband terminal delivers ship-to-shore and ship-to-ship broadband communication together with voice communication (at the same time) by utilising the latest generation Inmarsat I-4 satellites, which provide global coverage. Data communication services are offered with shared bandwidth (Standard IP at 432 kbps) and a dedicated data rate (Streaming IP at 256 kbps). The system also supports ISDN data service, multiple IP handsets, a host of parallel applications and FAX communication. No dedicated software is required and installation is simplified through a compact antenna unit with a diameter of around 60 cm and a weight of 20kg. High stability in communication links and guaranteed data streaming rates ensure network availability even under harsh environmental conditions. 

So, this would enable the MV Steve Irwin to communicate at all times and to stream or send video and audio in real time. It quite simply would catapult the ship into the 21st century of marine communication and make future campaigns significantly more effective. 

Where does it sit? Right here: 

I won't bore you with the technical details but if you want to find out more, you can have a look here: http://www.furuno.com/en/merchant/fleetbroadband/
As soon as this fundraiser ends, all money will be given to the Steve's comms officer to buy the system so it can be installed in time for campaign. 


About the ship and the crew

The MV Steve Irwin is a 40 years old Scot, 59.5 m (195 ft) long, and was purchased by the Sea Shepherd Conservation Society in 2005. To date it has mainly been used to protect the Southern Ocean Whale Sanctuary against illegal whaling operations but also on campaign against the overfishing of tuna in the mediterranean and to help maintain the integrity of the humpback whale nursery around Australia's Kimberley. 

In 2007, the ship was named the MV Steve Irwin in honour of the late animal and environmental conservationist who was planning to join Sea Shepherd on a whale defence campaign in Antarctica shortly before his death. Now Steve is on every campaign. 

During campaign the ship holds about 40 people (it's tight on the ship then) that are dedicated to the engine, deck, bridge, galley or media department. Right now, about 25 volunteers work on the ship to get it ready for campaign. 

Sea Shepherd runs 100% on donations, be it money, time, skills or items in-kind. Knowing the organisation up close for a while now, I can say that everything is done on a shoestring, everything, and it's truly amazing what can be achieved with relatively little money and pure dedication!


Right now, the crew is working 6 days a week from 8am to 6pm to fix the engine, sort out the comms system, prepare the small boats, get rid of the constant rust, and repair other bits and pieces that constantly break down on an old ship. Everyone is an unpaid volunteer. All they get is 3 meals a day (that's what we get the food donations for), a t-shirt & hoody that says "crew", and the before mentioned good ocean karma. 

I guess I should also mention that even though no one got ever hurt, every campaign comes with its dangers and the crew members know that they are risking their lives each time they are out at sea. A reliable satellite comms system will keep the crew a fair bit safer. 

Here are a couple more pictures showing the crew fighting rust on the Steve and the  Southern Ocean Base when the 3 big ships are in port (the Steve is the first ship on the right). 


What does Sea Shepherd do again?

Sea Shepherd is a movement, and a non-government organisation dedicated to protecting our oceans from poaching and conserving precious marine eco-systems. 

The Steve has spearheaded 7 of Sea Shepherd's 10 Antarctic whale defence campaigns, taking a key role in saving over 5,000 whales targeted for slaughter. 

Last year, Sea Shepherd undertook its first campaign against illegal toothfish poaching in Antarctica. This operation used innovative direct action tactics to fill a law enforcement void exploited by illegal toothfish operators. Two weeks into the operation the Sea Shepherd vessel Bob Barker found one of the most infamous toothfish vessels in history, the Thunder. For a record 110 days the Bob pursued this illegal vessel. Eventually the poachers scuttled their own ship to avoid INTERPOL finding evidence of their illegal activity. Luckily no-one was injured. The crew from the Thunder were rescued by Sea Shepherd and then handed over to local authorities. Sea Shepherd also handed over evidence of the poaching activities. Only recently, the Supreme Court of São Tomé and Príncipe has found three officers of the Thunder guilty. They have been sentenced to between 32 and 36 months in jail each for recklessness and forgery, and have been fined EUR 15 million for charges relating to pollution and damage to the environment. 

While the Bob pursued the Thunder, the Sea Shepherd vessel Sam Simon spent days and nights for weeks retrieving the fishing gear the Thunder had abandoned. The illegal gillnets were left trawling the ocean floor and would have ghost fished for a very long time. The Sam's crew reeled in 72 kilometres of those gillnets. 

A lot of awareness was generated around the illegal tooth fish operations. Whilst the Thunder is gone for good, the other 5 vessels of the poaching fleet were subsequently held in various ports in Asia where the authorities are investigating. Unfortunately one of them escaped Thailand a couple of weeks ago and is likely to continue its illegal fishing activities this Antarctic summer. Even more of a reason to quickly get the Steve ready!

The Japanese whaling fleet is returning to Antarctica in December to continue "the harvest" as they call it. Here is a video that summarises Sea Shepherd's anti-whaling campaign in Antarctica to date but also gives glimpses of the other campaigns around the world. Sea Shepherd is active on every continent to protect whales, dolphins, seals, sharks, turtles, toothfish, tuna, sea urchins, reef fish, krill and other ocean inhabitants from illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. There are even sea bird campaigns! :)

What else?

Please feel free to contact me, if I have left anything unanswered. Please use the "contribute now" button, and please share this page so the crowd gets bigger and with it the chances that we can fund most or all of the comms system. Please also let me know, if you have made a donation that I cannot link to you via your name or contact details on this page, just because the crew and I want to personally thank you!

Thanks again for reading all the way to the end. Now check out the perks, if not done yet! :)

You can find more about Sea Shepherd at seashepherd.org.au, Facebook or Instagram

PS: This is what the crew does when they receive donations.
story_txt:
Let's get the MV Steve Irwin a new satellite communication system! As most of you know I have been a Sea Shepherd volunteer for a few years now providing direct support to the ships and crew when they are down at our Southern Ocean Base in Melbourne (mainly organising food donations). Sea Shepherd's flagship, the MV Steve Irwin is currently docked here and getting repaired for the next ocean conservation campaign. Chatting with one of the captains the other day, I found out that the Steve is desperate to upgrade its marine satellite communication system. 
Why desperate? Because the current system is terribly outdated and communication is a key success factor on every campaign let alone a safety factor whilst out at sea. The current system's satellite phone and internet connection is very slow and often drops out completely...a problem when you need to get the latest photos and video footage of an encounter with poachers out quickly or when international media stations want to contact you for live interviews. The Steve's main role in the Sea Shepherd fleet is communication (and housing the helicopter). 
But apart from that the system is being used for secure communication and the tactical coordination between the Sea Shepherd ships (they are often not within radar range of each other to cover a wider area at sea and increase the chances to find poachers or the whaling fleet). The system is also being used for the latest weather updates (important in Antarctica where storms develop out of nowhere). But most importantly the system is used to contact the small boats when they are out and need to find their way back to the Steve before the weather changes or before they run out of fuel. 
Now, marine communication systems aren't cheap and the Steve is struggling right now to fund its emergency communication station (the part that radios in help before you jump on a liferaft). So the ship's official fundraising campaign is currently focussing on getting that sorted. 
However, the safety of the 40 or so crew onboard the Steve and the cause they are serving, protecting marine life for us and for future generations, is important to me. So, I have decided to run a private crowdfunding campaign. You are my crowd! Not a big crowd I must admit, and the amount we need is not small but I like a challenge and I like to believe that I am surrounded by people that care about the future of our oceans as much as I do. 
We have got some cool perks in exchange for your donations...including tickets to the amazing Wanderlust Yoga Festival! You can find more details below but let me thank you at this stage for reading this, for sharing this with people you think may be interested in contributing, and of course for your donation!!
For the oceans,
Andrea






Here is the plan: 
Fleet Broadband is not cheap...in fact, it will cost a whopping AUD 15,000, ouch! But operating it will only cost half of what the old system costs. So it's a good deal in the long run.  
Here is what I'm thinking...I did the same on a smaller scale 2 years ago (as some of you will remember) to raise funds for emergency equipment on another Sea Shepherd ship. With your help we can hopefully pull this one off as well. 
I will match what gets raised here up to AUD 1,000 and my employer will make an additional 4-digit contribution. I set the goal on this page to 5K so we have an achievable amount to raise. Fingers crossed though (and thumbs pressed, German style) that we can raise a 5-digit amount. The crew of the Steve will try to raise the remainder. 
Now, what's in it for you if you contribute to this fundraiser, apart from good ocean karma? Well, take a look at the perks listed on the side that the crew has put together. 
Also, the wonderful crew at Wanderlust have generoulsy donated 2 free tickets for their next 4-day Yoga Festival at Thredbo (Australia, 18 - 21 Feb 2016). I have been to their last festival and can tell you that it's sheer amazing so if I were you I would grab those tickets asap! They are currently selling for AUD 460 each and you can get them for just AUD 350, good ocean karma and all included! Check out the perks.


What else...I don't want anything for my birthday this month. Really, not even those little sweet sneaky presents on top of donations. Rather donate more please because the best present for me will be seeing that comms system getting installed on the ship! :)
I will keep you in the loop in terms of how much we ended up raising and let you know when the crew purchased and installed the new comms system.
And what, if we raise more than what we need, even the whole 15,000...wow, imagine! In that case I will post an update what additional items can be bought. Apart from that, the cost of fuel for the ship is about AUD 5,000 per day. Operation Icefish (more details further down) lasted for 110 days...
Now to the marine comms systemVoila, here is a hero shot of the object in need: 




It may not look like much but is a bit of a communication powerhouse. This is the FleetBroadband FB 500 that will hopefully replace the old VSAT unit. 




The Inmarsat FleetBroadband terminal delivers ship-to-shore and ship-to-ship broadband communication together with voice communication (at the same time) by utilising the latest generation Inmarsat I-4 satellites, which provide global coverage. Data communication services are offered with shared bandwidth (Standard IP at 432 kbps) and a dedicated data rate (Streaming IP at 256 kbps). The system also supports ISDN data service, multiple IP handsets, a host of parallel applications and FAX communication. No dedicated software is required and installation is simplified through a compact antenna unit with a diameter of around 60 cm and a weight of 20kg. High stability in communication links and guaranteed data streaming rates ensure network availability even under harsh environmental conditions. 
So, this would enable the MV Steve Irwin to communicate at all times and to stream or send video and audio in real time. It quite simply would catapult the ship into the 21st century of marine communication and make future campaigns significantly more effective. 



Where does it sit? Right here: 



I won't bore you with the technical details but if you want to find out more, you can have a look here: http://www.furuno.com/en/merchant/fleetbroadband/
As soon as this fundraiser ends, all money will be given to the Steve's comms officer to buy the system so it can be installed in time for campaign.   
About the ship and the crew The MV Steve Irwin is a 40 years old Scot, 59.5 m (195 ft) long, and was purchased by the Sea Shepherd Conservation Society in 2005. To date it has mainly been used to protect the Southern Ocean Whale Sanctuary against illegal whaling operations but also on campaign against the overfishing of tuna in the mediterranean and to help maintain the integrity of the humpback whale nursery around Australia's Kimberley. 
In 2007, the ship was named the MV Steve Irwin in honour of the late animal and environmental conservationist who was planning to join Sea Shepherd on a whale defence campaign in Antarctica shortly before his death. Now Steve is on every campaign. 
During campaign the ship holds about 40 people (it's tight on the ship then) that are dedicated to the engine, deck, bridge, galley or media department. Right now, about 25 volunteers work on the ship to get it ready for campaign.

Right now, the crew is working 6 days a week from 8am to 6pm to fix the engine, sort out the comms system, prepare the small boats, get rid of the constant rust, and repair other bits and pieces that constantly break down on an old ship. Everyone is an unpaid volunteer. All they get is 3 meals a day (that's what we get the food donations for), a t-shirt & hoody that says "crew", and the before mentioned good ocean karma. 
I guess I should also mention that even though no one got ever hurt, every campaign comes with its dangers and the crew members know that they are risking their lives each time they are out at sea. A reliable satellite comms system will keep the crew a fair bit safer. 
Here are a couple more pictures showing the crew fighting rust on the Steve and the  Southern Ocean Base when the 3 big ships are in port (the Steve is the first ship on the right).

story:
Short Summary

We are the Gunung Palung Orangutan Conservation Program (GPOCP), an orangutan conservation organization with roots in Boston, MA. We focus on protecting the Bornean orangutan population living in and around one of Indonesian Borneo's most magnificent protected areas, Gunung Palung National Park, located in West Kalimantan. Our conservation program has been around for 15 years, and we're well-known and trusted in the local community.

In 2009, we purchased a small piece of land in the National Park buffer zone, in a village called Pampang Harapan, and built our Bentangor Environmental Education Center. This is a community gathering and educational space, where we work to raise awareness and knowledge about orangutans and their rainforest habitat. We're proud to say that Bentangor is the only center of it's kind in this area of West Kalimantan! We maintain the center buildings themselves as well as a piece of forest (about 500 square meters) behind the center, which we use as a field trip area for elementary school students. Unfortunately, two months ago we were disappointed to discover that someone had cleared the land directly adjacent to ours, haphazardly chopping down and burning the trees, which has negatively affected our land as well. Now we've been informed that this land is for sale - and we want to purchase it.

Buying this land will serve two purposes: first, it will allow us to protect the small bit of forest that remains, and prevent further damage to Bentangor's facilities. Secondly, it will give us more area that can be used for educational activities! This will be a great space to show school groups the reality of forest destruction, and we hope to develop it into a natural laboratory for local students, especially our own volunteer youth group, to observe natural ecosystem regeneration and get hands-on experience with agro-forestry and forest restoration. Your donation can help us turn these hopes and dreams into action, while contributing to the long-term conservation of Bornean orangutans in the Gunung Palung landscape!

What We Need & What You Get

We are aiming to raise $5,000 for this project. We need:

  • $2,500 to purchase the land itself, at a cost of approximately $8/square meter
  • $1,000 to build some new structures once we've obtained the land, including a gazebo gathering space, seedling nursery, and educational signboards
  • $1,500 to cover logistical and staff costs for the 4-5 months it will take us to develop our newly acquired space

If we don't reach our goal, we'll prioritize purchasing the land itself with the funds we do raise. If we exceed our goal, we're going to allocate more money to environmental education activities at Bentangor. By engaging young people in conservation early, we can secure a future for orangutans and other rainforest biodiversity in the Gunung Palung landscape.

    The Impact

    Although we were sad and disappointed to see that the rainforest next door to Bentangor had been cleared, we're aiming to make lemonade out of lemons and take advantage of the fact that this area is now for sale. If we succeed in purchasing the land to expand our environmental education center, this will be a huge statement to the local community that, even after 15 years working in the Gunung Palung landscape, we are more serious than ever about protecting orangutans and their forest habitat! Every year, our environmental education programs positively impact over 4,000 area youth. Additionally, we work with adults in the area to promote "forest-friendly" livelihood activities, and much of this work happens at Bentangor. Our conservation model is truly community-based; we work with villages to find win-win solutions for people and wildlife, By purchasing this extra piece of land we will further solidify our presence in the area, building trust and grassroots support for conservation. We'd love for you, as our supporter, to be a part of this work.

      Risks & Challenges

      The biggest challenge will not be purchasing the land, but restoring the ecosystem that once existed here. Although it's just a small area, rainforest can take several years to grow back, but we're not intimidated by this challenge. Our staff, who are originally from the surrounding villages, are highly knowledgeable about local forests, and the restoration efforts will be led by our Environmental Education Coordinator, who is a trained botanist who has worked in the Gunung Palung area for his entire life. The best part is that we're going to involve dozens of local students and youth in the process, and these efforts will be supported by the local Departments of Education and Agriculture.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      If you can't donate, you can still help us! Share this page with your family and friends, and spread the word about Bornean orangutan conservation. Don't forget to check out our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram accounts as well!

story:
Mercy Rescue Trust is a small charity based in Kitale, Kenya set up and run by a small group of volunteer trustees in the UK. We run a baby rescue that takes in abandoned, orphaned and babies at risk, cares for them, loves them and educates them. We care for the children with the objective of finding loving local foster families or to support the children until they finish their education. We will then naturally support them to begin their adult life. 

As a small charity we struggle to find the funding or to have the profile we need to fundraise on a large scale. All of the money comes from dedicated sponsors and fundraising events organised by the trustees and other supporters in their own time. As well as the day to day running of the home and usual house hold bills, there are the administrative, medical and legal costs. Our current rented property has around 1.5 acres of arable land which is currently used to grow vegetables to provide food in a sustainable way. In previous years we have also been able to provide additional funds through selling surplus harvests. 
One of the stipulations of being a registered children's home in Kenya is that we own our own home on our own land. At the moment, we rent a lovely home with land but this is not considered to be secure. It would also be more cost effective on a monthly basis as we would not be paying rent and we could make it a more sustainable way of living through using natural resources such as fresh water and farm land. 
Land in Kenya is not cheap, particularly land which already has the infrastructure and access to the local community, hospitals and schools.  

A house has become available in Milimani, Kitale which is an ideal village with easy access to the town. Its sits on over an acre of land and has its own water supply which is desperately sought after. The owners of this house have offered it to Mercy Rescue Trust at a discounted price as they would like to see it go to such a worthy cause. The price they have offered us is 15 million Kenyan shillings which is about £95,000 with the current exchange rate. We would need to renovate, extend and build upon this to make it fit for our purpose which we estimate would cost a further £20,000. We have already had some very generous donations but in order to make this possible we will require a further £50,000 to cover all of the costs, including legal costs. 
This would allow us to finally own a property and focus on whats important, the babies. 



© 2015 Mercy Rescue Trust                    UK Charity No. 1121584

story:
Financing the 1 year Frogs & Forest thesis project of Eleana J. Reategui Vilchez, UNAP Iquitos.

We need help to finance the thesis & postgraduate project of my student Eleana Jesabell Reategui Vilchez  at the UNAP University of Iquitos. The research project is located in a remnant forest outside of Iquitos and has a duration of one year.  Budget must cover all costs like materials and equipment, fees, licenses, transport,  terrarias, food, local assistant, scientific materials, molecular genetic research etc. .

At the moment, Eleana has invested with help of her family and small jobs 15.000 Soles (5000 USD) in infrastructure (Frog Lab)  and camera gear (Canon Rebel EOS 3i). I am supporting the project also with in kind donations and training as the scientific advisor to her thesis. Eleana has finished her exams and must now start her thesis project to obtain the Biologist title. The same project is designed to go on and provide all data for her postgraduate study (MSc).

Eleana will  go on with my work on Dendrobatid frogs in Peru using the World Bank award winning sustainable production methods ZIRA and ZIR I designed in 1999.  In the thesis project, she is applying the ZIRA method in the scientific mode and just found a new species not recorded previously in the selected forest plot. 

Our outstanding research project on 4 Species of Ranitomeya which share a small remnant forest and live and breed side by side close together is totally new. We made some research on a model of 2 to 3 syntopic species in the Alto Cainarachi valley a few years ago- but this remnant forest at Iquitos surpasses all expectations: 4 species with similar colors and similar calls are forced together in a very limited habitat by the action of the famous Amazon Riverine Barrier. We want to know, how they share the habitat in all three dimensions, their limited breeding sites, and the food resources without problems and interferences. We know from captive breeding, that poison frog species from the same genus with a similar color and call can produce hybrids. Here we will be looking closely into this issue as it can be a severe problem for a species survival if the offspring is infertile or the genes of a species are "diluted" due to hybridization.

At the same time, we will show how it is possible to restore species and populations of poison frogs with the ZIRA method in a heavily depleted rainforest remnant where people extracted all breeding plants (bromeliads) and  stole the frogs for illegal pet trade.  

Sponsors will be mentioned in the thesis and in the scientific papers about the findings.

When a biology student leaves an university in Peru, he or she has no tools, no GPS, no digital macro camera, no digital recorder for frog calls, very limited field & species experience and therefore we senior specialits must help them. The research equipment acessible to the students of the UNAP  is in very bad shape and they have no trinocular digital  Photo Microscopes - so we must look for used microscopes and import them.(three types of research Photomicroscopes needed for this study: Preparation Zoom,  Inverted, and Compound High Magnification)! 

This is our story and if you have a rainforest terraria with frogs or like to help young students to get their titles and improve their skills- fund this project please.

The Budget:

1) Adaptation of room to Froglab

(New mains outlets, split air conditioner, working desk, table, chairs, paint)                                                                                                                           2.446,00 USD

2) Froglab materials 

Terrarium racks, aquaria and terraria, water filters, air pumps, LED lighting, food cultures ( one year)    

                                                                                                           2.403,00 USD 

3) Field research materials and equipment

Binoculars, head lamp, Canon 100 mm Macro Lens, used Microscopes, GPS,Data loggers, HD Action cam, bioacoustic research gear, fencing of plot,

                                                                                                                           6.558,00 USD 

4) Office materials

Computer, external Harddrive, Printer, ink cartridges, paper, Markers, software

                                                                                                                           1.100,00 USD

5) Transport to field plot ( 1 year)

Used Motocar, Gasoline, oil, repairs                                                      2.325,00 USD         

6) Food  (1 year)                                                                              3.421,00 USD

7) Field Assistant                                                                              500,00 USD

8) Froglab Energy ( 1 year)                                                              375,00 USD

                                                                           Total Amount:      19.128,00 USD

All donations will be directly used in this project according to the budget!

The results of this project will be published in a Sci journal and mayor sponsors will be mentioned in the paper. Fortunately we received also some in- kind donations from some enterprises so it will be possible to monitor key climatic data from the plot constantly (data logger) and include them into the  climate control software of the BIOPOD Terrarias to improve the keeping and breeding of those colorful species.   



 


Lo que necesitamos y lo que obtienes

Presenta más detalles:

  • explica cuánto financiamiento necesitas y a dónde va. Sé transparente y específico, la gente necesita confiar en ti para que quiera financiarte.
  • Cuéntale a la gente sobre tus recompensas exclusivas. ¡Haz que se entusiasmen!
  • Describe a dónde van los fondos si no logras la meta total.

El impacto

Explica tu campaña en mayor detalle y cuéntale a la gente la diferencia que hará su contribución:

  • explica por qué tu proyecto es valioso para el colaborador y para el mundo.
  • Describe tu historial de éxito en proyectos como este (si lo tienes).
  • Haz que la gente lo sienta real y genera confianza.

Riesgos y desafíos

Las personas valoran tu transparencia. Sé abierto y destácate al proveer perspectivas sobre los riesgos y obstáculos que puedes enfrentar en el camino hacia lograr tu meta.

  • Comparte lo que hace que te destaques para superar estos obstáculos.
  • Describe tu plan para solucionar estos desafíos.

Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar

Algunas personas no pueden colaborar, pero eso no significa que no puedan ayudar:

  • pídele a la gente que difunda tu campaña y que genere eco.
  • Recuérdale que use las herramientas para compartir de Indiegogo.

Y eso es todo.
story_txt:
Financing the 1 year Frogs & Forest thesis project of Eleana J. Reategui Vilchez, UNAP Iquitos.
 We need help to finance the thesis & postgraduate project of my student Eleana Jesabell Reategui Vilchez  at the UNAP University of Iquitos. The research project is located in a remnant forest outside of Iquitos and has a duration of one year.  Budget must cover all costs like materials and equipment, fees, licenses, transport,  terrarias, food, local assistant, scientific materials, molecular genetic research etc. .
At the moment, Eleana has invested with help of her family and small jobs 15.000 Soles (5000 USD) in infrastructure (Frog Lab)  and camera gear (Canon Rebel EOS 3i). I am supporting the project also with in kind donations and training as the scientific advisor to her thesis. Eleana has finished her exams and must now start her thesis project to obtain the Biologist title. The same project is designed to go on and provide all data for her postgraduate study (MSc).
Eleana will  go on with my work on Dendrobatid frogs in Peru using the World Bank award winning sustainable production methods ZIRA and ZIR I designed in 1999.  In the thesis project, she is applying the ZIRA method in the scientific mode and just found a new species not recorded previously in the selected forest plot. 
Our outstanding research project on 4 Species of Ranitomeya which share a small remnant forest and live and breed side by side close together is totally new. We made some research on a model of 2 to 3 syntopic species in the Alto Cainarachi valley a few years ago- but this remnant forest at Iquitos surpasses all expectations: 4 species with similar colors and similar calls are forced together in a very limited habitat by the action of the famous Amazon Riverine Barrier. We want to know, how they share the habitat in all three dimensions, their limited breeding sites, and the food resources without problems and interferences. We know from captive breeding, that poison frog species from the same genus with a similar color and call can produce hybrids. Here we will be looking closely into this issue as it can be a severe problem for a species survival if the offspring is infertile or the genes of a species are "diluted" due to hybridization. 
At the same time, we will show how it is possible to restore species and populations of poison frogs with the ZIRA method in a heavily depleted rainforest remnant where people extracted all breeding plants (bromeliads) and  stole the frogs for illegal pet trade.  
Sponsors will be mentioned in the thesis and in the scientific papers about the findings.
When a biology student leaves an university in Peru, he or she has no tools, no GPS, no digital macro camera, no digital recorder for frog calls, very limited field & species experience and therefore we senior specialits must help them. The research equipment acessible to the students of the UNAP  is in very bad shape and they have no trinocular digital  Photo Microscopes - so we must look for used microscopes and import them.(three types of research Photomicroscopes needed for this study: Preparation Zoom,  Inverted, and Compound High Magnification)!  
This is our story and if you have a rainforest terraria with frogs or like to help young students to get their titles and improve their skills- fund this project please.

story:
Hi everyone! My name is Ryan Pittman. I have a huge passion for growing my own food :). My goal is to inspire other people to learn how to do the same. I want to create and website that can bring people together towards this same goal. I am a huge believer in organic gardening without the use of pesticides or chemical fertilizers. I want to inspire people of all ages but i would like to focus a lot of my attention on getting young people excited about growing food and eating healthy. I believe young people hold the key to our planets future and education on organic food should be a huge part of our children's life. I despise GMO's and everything they stand for we need to break free from the corporate stronghold on our food supply and learn to grow our own!

My website plan is to create an online community of informative videos, articles and support from the community members.

I would like to offer organic heirloom seeds of many different types of plants and vegetables to get people growing in the right direction.

I want to help other small garden enthusiast by sharing their products on my website through article promotion and offering them a place to sell their products on my website.

I want to sell t-shirts and other clothing with my logo or awesome organic gardening logo's. Like NO GMO's or I GROW ORGANIC.

I would like to teach people A-Z about gardening. From how to start your seeds all the way to the best ways to harvest their crops and recipes to use for fresh food.

If you are willing to help me with my goal of starting this awesome project your money will go towards:

1.Purchasing and hosting of the website.

2.Design of the website and my time to fill it with the enormous amount of content I plan to make available to the public for free.

3.Creating an online community forum through the website.

4.Creating a recognizable name and logo (possibly a contest with a cash reward for the best logo design and company name.)

5.Advertising and marketing to get the name of my website out in the world.

6.Purchasing my organic seeds in bulk.

7. Getting my organization connected through social media 

 PERKS!!!!

$5

I will send you a hand written thank you on a post card :)


$10

10 delicious organic recipes! I will email these to you as soon as you contribute :)

$30

Will get you a custom packet of heirloom organic seeds along with seed starter and growing guides.


$50

Will get you a Beanie hat with the company name and or logo on it


$75

will get you a T-shirt like the one below (this is just an example T-shirt may be different) 


$350

If you really want to leave your mark on this campaign this perk will allow you to film your own gardening lesson and it will be posted on our website for the whole world to see :) 



I can't thank you enough for taking the time to look at my idea. Even if you feel you can't contribute I welcome any and all ideas you might have to offer that could help my cause. You are all awesome.

Thanks a million.

Ryan Pittman

story:
Earthship Biotecture plans to build an off-grid, self-sustained home for a family living on Six Nations of the Grand River Territory, in the summer of 2015. 

The Haudenosaunee family faces the colonial injustice of a housing crisis, and the countless obstacles which make getting a housing loan next to impossible for people who live far below the poverty line.

The family is in desperate need of a healthier and more cost effective shelter, as they have been living in a condemned trailer for years. The trailer has several holes where you can see straight through to the outside, a rodent infestation, mold, old brass pipes that get clogged constantly, next to no insulation, and a leaking roof. The owner does not think it will make it through the winter. She supports her daughter, who is a single mother, and 4 grandchildren, aged 4, 8, 11 and 15. She is their only family.

She will be welcoming all peoples to watch, participate and learn from this building process. She looks forward to being a part of showing that it takes grassroots people power to address the housing and energy crisis.

The new off grid home will be built using Architect, Michael Reynold's, Earthship design.  The Earthship Home features:

 - Thermal & Solar Heating and Cooling - Solar & Wind Electricity

 - Contained Sewage Treatment - Building with Natural & Recycled Materials 

- Water Harvesting

 - Internal Food Production  

During the building process, we will host a free Sustainable Building Workshop for members of Six Nations interested in construction skill development. Our hope is to provide members of the community - especially youth-  with the skills needed to replicate the building, and an opportunity to develop a local sustainable building crew.   Through fundraising and public outreach, it is our hope that we will generate enough interest and financial support during this project, that we may continue to build and teach in other Indigenous communities throughout Canada.  

Primary Goals:  

- to prove that sustainable and affordable methods of housing exist.  

- to prove that with organization and skill development, communities can provide this housing for themselves with locally sourced labour and materials, through hands-on education and training.  

- to engage a community in an environmentally conscious project, to enhance community knowledge and understanding of sustainability concepts.  

- to provide a family with economic independence from fluctuating energy and water costs.  

- to offer a positive, and practical solution to a country wide housing and environmental crisis.

We need to raise $100, 000 for this project through donations and sponsorships.  Please consider making any contribution you can.

Who Are We

We are The Sustainability Education Centre, which is home to Earthship Canada Headquarters.  You can learn more about us:

www.sustainabilityedc.com

www.earthship.com


Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Share this story with your contacts and through social media
  • Visit our website for updates and volunteer opportunities www.sustainabilityedc.com

story:
The Navajo People Are Being Poisoned by Radioactivity from Uranium Mines. Natural Beekeeping, Pollinator Gardens and Medicinal Mushrooms Can Help Them Stay Healthy and Heal Navajo Land! 


Santiago Romero & Navajo Bee Project

I was born at the Santa Fe Indian Hospital and grew up in the heart of Los Angeles but visited New Mexico every summer. My father mentored with renowned Native American artist, sculptor and author Roxanne Swentzell and I discovered the joy of sculpting. Working around Roxanne's farm and helping with her creative projects was my doorway to art and a passion for Native American rights and environmental protection.

I graduated from Dartmouth with a degree in environmental science and a studio art minor. After returning to Santa Fe, I began working with ceramic sculpture under the watchful gaze of my father and his uncle, two renowned southwest artists. 

A trip to Navajo Land in 2014 opened my eyes to the environmental degradation wrought by eighty years of uranium mining leaving over two thousand open mines that leak radioactivity into Navajo communities. Natural beekeeping, native plants and medicinal mushrooms can heal the land around these mines and protect the Navajo communities. 

It a massive project and long overdue, but your donation will allow us to provide the Navajo with honeybees to pollinate native plants, pollinator gardens and even mushrooms to detoxify the soil!

Join the Hive!

The Problem:

This is a map of some of the over 2,000 uranium mines leaking radiation on Navajo land. Some of these mines have been open since WW2 and have caused massive damage to Navajo people, livestock and plant life. Many are close to rivers that spread the radioactivity hundreds of miles downstream. This is no longer just a Navajo problem, but everyone's problem.


The Solution:

The Navajo People have received funds to cap these mines so they no longer leak radiation. However there is a massive amount of work that needs to be done to clean up over seventy years worth of radioactivity and destruction to human health, rural economies, livestock and plant life.

This summer we will begin placing honeybees, native bee nests, medicinal mushrooms and other pollinators on Navajo Land. 

Including:

~ Honey bees to pollinate plants and provide honey to create income for their Navajo beekeepers. 

~ Native Bee Nests to encourage the over 4,000 types of solitary bees to thrive on the land and pollinate a variety of plants, tress and fruits.

~ Bat Houses to encourage bats to live on the lands to provide natural pest control.

~ Native grasses, flowers and shrubs to help the soil revive.

~ Bee gardens full of flowers, grasses and shrubs that bees, moths, hummingbirds, and other pollinators love.

~ Mushroom inoculation of the radioactive sites based on Paul Stamet's research to help increase the rate of detoxification by 10,000 fold. 

~ Invite you to visit Navajo Land and see for yourself the awesome work your donation will make possible. Participate in celebration ceremonies for the bee hives and gardens. 




What We Need & What You Get

We are trying to raise $25,000 to gift 100 hives to Navajo people who have been affected by these mines. These hives will not only heal the land, but provide an ongoing source of income from the honey and wax they produce. Additionally, we want to plant 25 acres of native plants around the mine sites to provide pollen and nectar for the bees. 

We have some awesome perks for you including Navajo Bee Project stickers, T Shirts, and coffee mugs! We will name hives and bee gardens after you and even invite you to Navajo Land!


The Impact

This is the first time since World War Two that the issue of uranium mining's aftermath is being addressed with an environmentally sound approach. Natural beekeeping is the perfect method to reclaim the damaged land, pollinate new plant growth and provide income for the Navajo.  The Navajo Bee Project is the first step and we want you to experience Navajo culture!

Risks & Challenges

Natural Beekeeping is risky. We don't kill the queen every year to increase productivity like commercial beekeepers do. We don't treat the hives with miticides or pesticides nor feed the bees sugar water. Instead, we support the hive to be as healthy as possible. All our bees are sourced from natural beekeepers in the Southwest so they are acclimated to the climate, conditions and altitude. 

The Navajo people are committed to making the project a success and all we need is  your support! Please make a donation of any amount and Join the Hive!


Other Ways You Can Help

We give you a big Navajo welcome for just a buck, but you can also help in other ways! We are a small team centered in Santa Fe. Please help us get the word out!

Join the Hive!

Mentors:

We created Navajo Bee Project based on the work of Coal County Beeworks in Kentucky who pioneered the use of honeybees in reclaiming mining lands.

Check out their video!



Paul Stamets has done incredible work using mushrooms to revitalize lands damaged by war, oil, toxins and radioactivity. Check out his Ted Talk on using mushrooms to save the world!

Natural beekeeping is the perfect method to reclaim the damaged land, pollinate new plant growth and provide income for the Navajo.  The Navajo Bee Project is the first step and we want you to experience Navajo culture!


    Risks & Challenges Natural Beekeeping is risky. We don't kill the queen every year to increase productivity like commercial beekeepers do. We don't treat the hives with miticides or pesticides nor feed the bees sugar water. Instead, we support the hive to be as healthy as possible. All our bees are sourced from natural beekeepers in the Southwest so they are acclimated to the climate, conditions and altitude. 
The Navajo people are committed to making the project a success and all we need is  your support! Please make a donation of any amount and Join the Hive!

    Other Ways You Can Help We give you a big Navajo welcome for just a buck, but you can also help in other ways! We are a small team centered in Santa Fe. Please help us get the word out!
Join the Hive!
Mentors:
We created Navajo Bee Project based on the work of Coal County Beeworks in Kentucky who pioneered the use of honeybees in reclaiming mining lands.
Check out their video!


Paul Stamets has done incredible work using mushrooms to revitalize lands damaged by war, oil, toxins and radioactivity. Check out his Ted Talk on using mushrooms to save the world!

story:
Who is Mazao NGO?

Mazao is an international NGO focused on rural development and food security, using the approaches of social business and participatory education to develop actions that generate wellbeing in a long-term perspective.  Since 4 years Mazao works with family farmers in Katanga (DR Congo), strengthening local technical capacity and  establishing agro-ecological value chains,   www.mazao.cd 

 

The Food Forest Program offers a concrete solution to climate change and food insecurity:

  1. Through the use of Agro-ecology and Carbon Farming we can absorb tons of C02 while at the same time regenerate soils and increase biodiversity.
  2. The variety of foods grown in the mini-food-forests ensure a diversified diet and a regular revenue to family farmers that look after the forests 
  3. Among the plants that grow in the Food Forests there is the Moringa Oleifera, called Tree of Miracles for its highly nutritious properties.
  4. The leaves of Moringa are purchased from family farmers and processed into high-quality Moringa powder. The final product is sold in international markets (Europe and Asia), through a highly sustainable trade model called "Part-Ecology”.
  5. Mazao developed an ethical and sustainable brand called FOOD FOREST and its first product called JustMoringa.

BUSINESS MODEL

"FOOD FOREST & PART-ECOLOGY"

 

Our objective in Congo: 

140 Food Forests in 2017 and 3000 in the next 3 years

 

The PART-ECOLOGY system entails:

  • A fair price paid to family farmers + 20% of the earned profit (generated by the sale of Moringa powder)  employed for actions chosen by farmers in the following fields: water, energy, transport or rotating savings (Likilimba)
  • 80% of the earned profits are re-invested to grow new Food Forests - triggering a positive feedback loop.
  • Products are grown following the principle of Agro-ecology and Carbon Farming: approaches that increase soil carbon and biodiversity, mitigate climate change, increase / restore soil fertility, build healthy soils that hold much more water, making crops more resilient on the face of drought.
  • The use of participatory learning tools and the endless sharing of knowledge with/between farmers’ groups. These approaches are used at all stages of the training and in the value chain decision making process.

    Few advantages of the Part-Ecology value chain:​

    1. This type of value chain is usually defined as “long” since it requires shipments of goods from a continent to another. However part-ecology secures the benefits of a "short" value chain (zero environmental impact, more income to producers, increases local governance, etc).
    2. The amount of time employed for the production of Moringa leaves must remain marginal to the core activities of family farmers, in order to avoid dependence on international demand. The focus is on the development of diverse and resilient local value chains. Central are therefore the harvests of the other crops/trees that grow in the food forests (Papaya, Banana plantain, Beans, Avocado, etc ..).

    It’s a holistic model, that can have a social, economic and environmental long-term impact. The core objective of part-ecology is to enhance the resilience of all eco-systems involved.​

     

    Impacts

    Environment​

    • Carbon-Negative-value-chain: the overall carbon emissions released into the atmosphere (transport, packaging, energy consumption, calories employed etc) are lower than the overall amount of the carbon sequestration in the soil (through photosynthesis, biochar, etc).
    • Increase of biodiversity; reforestation
    • Increase of the degree of resilience of eco-systems (bio-diversity, water availability, drought resistance etc)

    Social:

    • Increase of the degree of resilience of humans involved (food availability in the dry season, diversification of income generating activities, land-grabbing resistance etc).
    • Knowledge sharing: create the conditions to facilitate the exchange of agro-ecological knowledge among farmers
    • Empowerment of communities and of the most vulnerable through the use of inclusive tools

    Economic​:

    • Microeconomics: increase of the family budget and the purchasing power of farmers, ensure a regular revenue throughout the year

    • Macroeconomics: development of local economies (local food systems)

    • Increase of the value of land of each small-holder, a deterrent for land-grabbing.

    • Job creation: 13 people employed by Mazao to run the small Moringa processing factory

    Nutritional:

    Reinforcement/diversification of diet: from 6 to more than 10 different foods are grown in the food forests + the Moringa leaves.

    Dry Moringa leaves (gram by gram) contain 17 times the calcium of milk, 3 times the potassium of bananas, 10 times the vitamin A of carrots, 25 times more iron than spinach, 9 times the yogurt proteins and 0.5 times the vitamin C of oranges.

     

     

    What we need and what do you gain?

    We need 30.000 Euros to launch this new business model and have a direct impact on 140 peasant families.​

    Thanks to the fund-raising we will:​ 

    1. Launch another 140 Food Forests in 2017 (40 were planted in 2016  through a pilot project). 

    In detail you will finance:

    • Permaculture training for 140 family farmers
    • Constant follow-up of Forests
    • Support the establishment of local supply chains
    • Training to the use of Moringa leaves and training to process leaves ecologically and hygienically 
    • The construction of two solar dryers, a spin dryer and other tools to naturally process Moringa leaves

    2. Production of 3000 unit packs of Moringa powder; the commercialisation in Europe and Asia. This will trigger the loop process (new production of Moringa, new forests, new actions decided by farmers according to their needs and so on)

    Thanks to your help, we can show that this model works and spread it worldwide. Imagine Food Forest corridors across tropical areas, green strips of edible nature that reverse climate change and provide abundance!​

     

     

    Your contribution will enable you to:

    Taste our pure Moringa powder and test the benefits on your body! A complete natural food supplement with the potential to end malnutrition in Africa!

    JustMoringa, the first product of the innovative Food Forest brand, will improve your daily diet and health in a sustainable, ethical and natural way.

    JustMoringa powder is made through the selection of only the greener and most tender leaves. A natural drying process assures best quality and maintenance of all nutritious properties. The result is a 100% natural and pure powder - amongst the purest in the market

     

    Check out all the awards that you can get by contributing to this campaign!

    Exclusive Moringa Kit:

    - Moringa seeds

    - Super-fine powder of Moringa Oleifera

    - Dehydrated leaves of Moringa Oleifera

    Food Forest gadgets :

    - Forest Food 2017 Calendar

    - Food Forest T-shirt

    Acknowledgments:

    - E-card with thanks

    - Tree planted in your name

    - Video message of thanks from a Food Forest Village

    Forest Food 2017 Calendar 

    Food Forest T-shirt

     

    Other ways to support?

    If you would like to help our cause but you have little disposable income at the moment, it does not mean you cannot support us!

    • Send the link of the campaign to 10 friends and make them understand the importance of a small donation.
    • Use Facebook to "share" the campaign and maybe add a few lines to support our cause.

    Just a few minutes of your time would really be precious and would make the difference! You would be helping us anyhow!

story:
Täglich werden ca. 30 Hektar Feld, Wald oder Wiese zu Wohnraum umgebaut. Seit 2004 wurden ca. 200.000 Hektar Grünland oder Wald zu Ackerland umgearbeitet, was bedeutet, dass jeden Tag ca. 80 Hektar Lebensraum der heimischen Tier- und Pflanzenwelt verloren geht. Es gibt kaum mehr Versteckmöglichkeiten für Wild oder Lebensräume für Insekten oder Kleinsäugetiere. Vor allem im Gäuboden um Straubing herrscht eine regelrechte Agrarwüste.

Die Grünstreifen und die ausgedehnten Hecken müssen jährlich weiter der Industrialisierung unserer Landwirtschaft weichen. Bienen und andere Insekten werden durch den großflächigen Einsatz von Insektiziden zu "bedrohten Arten". Feldränder, die früher noch Heimat von unzähligen Insekten, Nagern und Pflanzen waren, werden vorbeugend mit Pestiziden behandelt. Dies hat zur Folge, dass heutzutage die Feldränder mehr oder weniger steril sind und somit für Tiere oder Pflanzen kaum oder keinen Schutz oder Lebensraum mehr bietet.

Feuchtbiotope oder auch nur "Feldsteinhaufen", welche aus in Feldern gefundenen Steinen bestehen, verschwinden in rasender Geschwindigkeit, obwohl sie Lebensräume von zahlreichen - teils gefährdeten – Tier- und Pflanzenarten sind.

Derzeit stehen 478 Namen auf der Roten Liste von bedrohten oder ausgestorbenen Tier- oder Pflanzenarten allein in Deutschland. 28 Prozent hiervon gelten als bestandsgefährdet, 32 Arten sind bereits ausgestorben. Unsere Feldhamster, der Kiebitz oder der Kampfläufer sind bedroht und werden wohl auch früher oder später ganz verschwunden sein.

Wir sind eine Gruppe von Junglandwirten, Landwirtskindern und teils Ökolandwirten, die zeigen möchten, dass es auch anders geht.

Unser Projekt gliedert sich in 2 Phasen. Für Phase 1 stellen wir eine Fläche von 37.040 qm, die im Gäuboden liegt, zur Verfügung. Auf dieser Fläche wollen wir natürliche Biotope anlegen. Diese Biotope sollen alles bieten, was unsere Tier- und Pflanzenwelt benötigt, aber auch gleichzeitig den Sponsoren unseres Projektes etwas bringen.

Durch Baum-, Hecken-, oder Bienenpatenschaften können Sie der Natur helfen und gleichzeitig Bio- Obst, Honig oder Saft bekommen.

Außerdem möchten wir diese Flächen auch gerne für Schulausflüge als Naturerlebnisflächen oder Naturlehrpfad zur Verfügung stellen, um unseren Kindern die Natur in der heutigen Zeit wieder etwas näher zu bringen.

Phase 1: Besteht darin die vorhandene Fläche so natürlich wie möglich zu gestalten und dennoch einen Ertrag daraus zu erwirtschaften.

Phase 2: Wenn genug Interessenten zusammenkommen, würden wir einen Verein gründen, um derartige Projekte überregional umzusetzen. Dazu würden Flächen erworben und anschließend in unser Konzept übernommen werden. Auch sollen Flächen geschaffen werden, auf denen Gemüse so naturnah wie möglich gepflanzt wird. Hierfür würden weitere 40.100 qm zur Verfügung stehen.

Planung der Umsetzung von Phase 1:

Anlegen einer artenreichen Bepflanzung von Bäumen und Hecken, die möglichst vielen Tieren einen Lebensraum bieten. Nach Möglichkeit sollen alte Obstsorten in Kombination mit verschiedenen Laubbäumen gepflanzt werden. Die Fläche wird durch eine möglichst abwechslungsreiche, durchgehende Hecke eingerahmt, die vielen Tieren einen natürlichen Lebensraum bietet. Feuchtbiotope sollen als Lebensraum für Libellen, Lurche, Frösche und Vögel angelegt werden. Ebenso sollen Natursteinhaufen als Lebensraum für Eidechsen oder Mäuse entstehen.

Insgesamt planen wir 390 Bäume und 2.000 qm Hecke, 3 Natursteinhaufen und 2 Feuchtbiotope anzulegen. Auf dieser gesamten Fläche werden dann anschließend 6 Bienenvölker verteilt.

Die vorhandene Grasfläche wird nicht gemäht, sondern einmal im Jahr von einem Schäfer abgeweidet werden, um im Gras brütende Vögel nicht zu stören oder zu vertreiben.

Selbstverständlich verzichten wir komplett auf Spritzmittel und Düngung.

Die Aberntung der Bäume wird nicht maschinell stattfinden, sondern per Hand um die Bäume so wenig wie möglich zu belasten.

Um den Sponsoren unseres Projekts die höchste Qualität zu bieten, werden wir die Flächen von Bioland zertifizieren lassen.

Gerne können Sie uns besuchen und mitmachen.

Wie können Sie uns helfen?

Baumpatenschaften:

Wir bieten 3 Arten von Baumpatenschaften an:

  • Die Lebenslange Obstbaumpatenschaft für 300 Euro:

Bei dieser Patenschaft wird ein Hochstamm gepflanzt, bei dem sie ab 2016 jährlich entweder ca. 20 Kg Obst oder die dementsprechende Menge Saft bekommen. Außerdem wird ein Schild mit Ihrem Namen an diesem Baum angebracht und Sie bekommen selbstverständlich ein Foto davon. Diese Patenschaft gilt nach der Einmalzahlung lebenslang oder bis zum Absterben des Baums.

  • Die jährliche Obstbaumpatenschaft für 50 Euro:

Wir Pflanzen einen Baum von dem Sie ab ca. 2017 Obst bekommen. Sie bekommen dann ca. 20 Kg Obst oder die dementsprechende Menge an Saft. Es wird ebenfalls ein Schild mit Ihrem Namen an dem Baum angebracht und sie bekommen ein Foto davon. Die Patenschaft gilt immer nur für ein Jahr und kann jährlich verlängert werden.

  • Die Nutzbaumpatenschaft für 35 Euro:

Es wird ein für die Natur nützlicher Baum (Linde, Akazie, o.ä.) gepflanzt. Es wird ein Schild mit Ihrem Namen an dem Baum angebracht und sie bekommen ein Foto davon. Außerdem bekommen Sie ein Glas Honig mit 500 Gramm aus unserem Projekt. Diese Patenschaft gilt immer nur für ein Jahr und kann jährlich verlängert werden.

Sonstige:

  • Staudenpatenschaften für 20 Euro:

Wir Pflanzen eine Hecke (Hagebutte, Schlehe, Holunder o.ä.) und sie bekommen ein Glas Marmelade von dieser Hecke. Auch diese Patenschaft gilt immer nur für ein Jahr und kann jährlich verlängert werden.

  • Bienenpatenschaft für 40 Euro:

Sie übernehmen die Patenschaft für ein Bienenvolk auf unseren Grundstücken. Die Arbeiten an den Bienenvölkern werden durch einen erfahrenen Imker durchgeführt und sie bekommen ein Kg Honig von Ihren eigenen Bienen. Diese Patenschaft gilt ebenso für nur ein Jahr und kann jährlich verlängert werden.

Besuche auf den Projektflächen sind nach Fertigstellung mit Terminabsprache gerne möglich.

Bei Projektstart wird eine Homepage angelegt, auf der der aktuelle Fortschritt sichtbar sein wird, auch was angesiedelte Arten betrifft!

Sollten Sie Fragen zu unserem Projekt haben oder wenn Sie mitwirken möchten, können Sie uns gerne Ihre Telefonnummer oder E-Mail-adresse zukommen lassen, wir melden uns dann schnellstmöglich bei Ihnen.

Uns ist bewusst, dass wir das nicht alles von heute auf morgen im Alleingang lösen können. Aber wir möchten unser Bestes tun, um so natürlich wie möglich zu arbeiten und zu leben.

ein Schild mit Ihrem Namen an dem Baum angebracht und sie bekommen
ein Foto davon. Außerdem bekommen Sie ein Glas Honig mit 500 Gramm
aus unserem Projekt. Diese Patenschaft gilt immer nur für ein Jahr
und kann jährlich verlängert werden.

Sonstige:



Staudenpatenschaften für 20 Euro:


Wir Pflanzen eine
Hecke (Hagebutte, Schlehe, Holunder o.ä.) und sie bekommen ein Glas
Marmelade von dieser Hecke. Auch diese Patenschaft gilt immer nur für
ein Jahr und kann jährlich verlängert werden.



Bienenpatenschaft für 40 Euro:


Sie übernehmen
die Patenschaft für ein Bienenvolk auf unseren Grundstücken. Die
Arbeiten an den Bienenvölkern werden durch einen erfahrenen Imker
durchgeführt und sie bekommen ein Kg Honig von Ihren eigenen Bienen.
Diese Patenschaft gilt ebenso für nur ein Jahr und kann jährlich
verlängert werden.


Besuche auf den Projektflächen sind
nach Fertigstellung mit Terminabsprache gerne möglich.
Bei Projektstart wird eine Homepage
angelegt, auf der der aktuelle Fortschritt sichtbar sein wird, auch
was angesiedelte Arten betrifft!

Sollten Sie Fragen zu unserem Projekt
haben oder wenn Sie mitwirken möchten, können Sie uns gerne Ihre
Telefonnummer oder E-Mail-adresse zukommen lassen, wir melden uns
dann schnellstmöglich bei Ihnen.

Uns ist bewusst, dass wir das nicht
alles von heute auf morgen im Alleingang lösen können. Aber wir
möchten unser Bestes tun, um so natürlich wie möglich zu arbeiten
und zu leben.

story:
Play a big role in building Human-Dolphin Partnerships for excellent Global Stewardship!

Help us launch the first of its kind Dolphin Ambassador Program.  A multi-level certification program that uniquely combines fun & educational online classes for all ages, real-life dolphin experiences and scientific research, special events with the experts and environmental action projects.  Our Mission is to empower humanity with practical steps towards building meaningful lifelong relationships with our amazing dolphin friends. In other words, we'll train YOU to be a dolphin expert!

Online course topics include:

Dolphin Anatomy
Positive Reinforcement
Communication Research
Marine Mammal Rescue
History & Future of Human-Dolphin Relations
Dolphin Emoji Games - 2 way communication
Inspiring Lessons from Dolphins
Amazing True Dolphin Reports
Dolphin Assisted Therapy
Enrichment & Dolphin Games
Echolocation
Myths vs Facts
How to Help Dolphins
Whales & other Marine Mammals

Live event experiences include:

Online presentations & chats with experts 
In-person special events at Dolphin embassies
In-water Dolphin interactions & research sessions
In-water Dolphin Emoji Games - 2 way communication
Environmental Action Projects
Citizen Science Projects

Your donation helps:

  • to build the online content for the Dolphin Ambassador Program
  • to maintain and grow the Ambassador training
  • to fund dolphin communication research
  • to fund & promote environmental projects directly benefiting dolphins  

 

To express our gratitude for your generosity we have wonderful Thank You Gifts. Check out these exciting options to match your enthusiasm for Human-Dolphin Partnerships.

Click on each "Perks" category to see your Thank You gifts. 

If fundraising exceeds our goal, the money will be used to expand the Dolphin Ambassador Program content for use in schools.

Where your donation goes:

to the 501(c)(3) nonprofit Global Heart, Inc.

story:
Elabora is an innovative project brought into being by the meeting of people who have been working for years in the field of university and corporate training. Its focus is to conceive, propose and realize empowering strategies for individuals and organizations meant to understand, strengthen and make the most of each and everyone’s peculiarities and talents as well as of the collective intelligence that emerges from every group.

Our priority is to highlight and educate potentialities and resources that belong to everyone: this is the main drive that leads us to believe in our work. We want to promote and support people’s change and flourishing by helping in the expression of their hidden talents and by motivating them to a balanced growth, in harmony with themselves and their environment.

Furthermore, Elabora aims at conceiving, proposing and realizing plans that can make the difference by experimenting with new tools and possibilities. We mean to create a new mix of activities focused on value-rational actions to show the reality of another way of thinking economics. We strongly believe that cooperation among different subjects – institutions, companies, citizens – can result in a win-win situation where profit is just a part of the whole, together with passion, active commitment and pleasure. We are convinced that our future can be built on renewed relations and values and, with your help, we mean to prove it!

NarniAround – Adopt a trail

“Everyone has the power to make the world a better place” (Sergio Bambarén)

The township of Narni, the Center of Italy, looks out on the wide Terni valley rising from a steep cliff in the Nera gorge, with the river flowing underneath its ancient walls on its way through the forested hills around Stifone and Nera Montoro. These woods are crisscrossed by trails and roads: some tracks are more difficult, suitable for expert trekkers, others are easier, perfect for whoever wants to spend a pleasant day among Nature’s sounds and perfumes.

All these magic trails have a thing in common: they start at the heart of the beautiful medieval town of Narni. They have been taken care of for a long time, made secure and enjoyable, but lately, due to long years of crisis and dwindling resources, are neglected and the wonderful environment that accompany our lives and survives us, to become an heritage for those who will follow risks being forgotten.

Elabora wants to start from here: Narni, the beautiful heart of Italy, and its potentially wonderful network of walkways. Our dream is to repair and revive the more important trails: to do so, we need to fix up the wooden handrails that protect walkers from falls, to mow weeds, to set up adequate signs and waypoints and lots of further initiatives aimed at transforming a dilapidated reality into a rich and vibrant experience for all those who would love to hike in the wilds of this area.

These are the objectives we plan to accomplish thanks to your support:

On the economic plan, we will reach a growing segment of the tourist market, achieving a better visibility of the district, an increase in commercial exchange and the possibility to figure our more projects enjoying the positive shine of this first enterprise;

Furthermore, we will create new job opportunities for young people and strengthen the existing network of activities toward a consistent growth;

On the ecological-environmental plan, we will attract consciously involved people who enjoy our district in a non-polluting way and allow for a minute surveillance of the territory, the reestablishment of bonds and ties with it – with positive repercussions on the local community – and its general revitalization;

On the social plan, we will strengthen socio-cultural processes that renew solidarity and care for each other and for the commons, two neglected forces from which to start rebuilding citizenship and rediscovering the taste for a good life, in line with the best cultural trends of the moment.

“The Road goes ever on and on / Down from the door where it began. / Now far ahead the Road has gone, / And I must follow, if I can, / Pursuing it with eager feet, / Until it joins some larger way / Where many paths and errands meet. / And whither then? I cannot say” (John R. R. Tolkien)

Risks & Challenges

Even if it all may seem easy and reasonable, bureaucracy, mistrust and bad previous examples are to be coped with. Elabora might be one of a thousand smiling robbers with a sweet tongue and deep pockets. It might be, but… we mean to be the difference, it is our mission and vision just to be a touch corporate, so lies and embezzlement would take us nowhere. Our bookkeeping will be transparent, you will always know what your money is for and you will see what it helped to realize.

We have already established trustful relations with the government of Narni, that patronizes our campaign and is quite happy to be supported by a youthful, talented and enthusiastic team. They will help us to overcome procedural difficulties and to spend your money wisely. We will need time to rebuild trust, it is one of the main challenges we wish to address, but we are convinced we need to find ways to do it, as it has been easy to destroy and no one seems to know how to mend it. We want to try our hands at it with value-rational actions and commitment!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you like our campaign please help us to get the word out and make it known far and wide! And if you just can’t contribute be our friend and supporter, visit our pages and like what you find: every little click will take us a step further. And every mention of our cause as well.

To this end, remember to use the Indiegogo share tools. 

See you on the road to Narni!
