story:
Adopt a tree in critical danger of extinction in a Tropical Dry Forest //Adopta un árbol en peligro crítico de extinción en un bosque seco tropical.

This campaign has ended here on IndieGoGo, but you can still adopt a tree via our website: 
http://www.tananeos.org/en/adopt-a-tree/

Tropical Dry Forests are among the most threatened ecosytems on the planet. Extensive deforestation has reached almost 100%. 

Worldwide, only 1.5% of the natural vegetation of these forests survives. And we want to contribute to save what's left and even try to increase the Tropical Dry Forest.  

//

(Español)

Los Bosques Secos Tropicales se encuentran dentro de los ecosistema más amenazados del planeta. Su deforestación ha alcanzado casi el 100 %.

A nivel mundial, sólo el 1,5 % de la vegetación natural de estos bosques sobrevive. 
Desde nuestra Reserva Natural queremos contribuir a proteger y aumentar la superficie de estos bosques. 

That´s why we are going to protect and plant trees in a dry forest. Lots of them. 

With our campaign you can adopt a tree in the Natural Reserve Los Tananeos in the north of Colombia, and be sure your tree is being taken care of to guarantee it´s survival. 

//

(Español)

Por eso vamos a proteger y plantar árboles...Muchos árboles.

Con esta campaña puedes adoptar un árbol en la Reserva Natural Los Tananeos en el norte de Colombia. Nosotros nos encargaremos de  garantizar su supervivencia dentro del bosque.


"Lo que le pase a la Tierra, les pasa también a los hijos de la Tierra...

...La Tierra no pertenece a los hombres, el hombre pertenece a la Tierra.  El hombre no ha tejido la red de la vida, él sólo es un hilo de esa red.  Lo que le haga a la red, se lo hace a si mismo"

Palabras del Cacique Seattle. Año: 1855


Para ver más información en español te invitamos a visitar nuestra web: www.tananeos.org//


Where?

Natural Reserve Los Tananeos is located at only 30 minutes from the capital of the department of Cesar, in the foothills of the Serranía del Perija, Colombia. Since it´s inception in 2010, the reserve has become a benchmark for the conservation of fauna and flora in the region.

The Tananeos tree, which gives the name to the Reserve can be found, but also Ceiba, Cedar, Laurel, and Willow trees, Caracolíes, Cocoa and many other varieties that dot the Reserve with the color of life.


Why?

Do you know the importance of Tropical Dry Forests for our planet?

These bio-diverse ecosystems are extremely resistant to weather fluctuations due to climate change. 
They are also the first forest ecosystem on the Colombian Caribbean coast that provide a resting place, food, and shelter to millions of migratory birds of over 60 species that land on the coast after their trip crossing the Caribbean Sea.

Tropical Dry Forests have been destroyed for timber, mineral extraction, and commercial farming. Their destruction has negatively impacted the communities that depend on these forests,  affects the global climate, and causes the extinction of many species specific to this ecosystem.

Our mission as a Natural Reserve is to contribute to the conservation and restoration of our Tropical Dry Forest and protect its main species from extinction.

We are already on our way...

With the support of Patrimonio Natural and USAID, we have built a greenhouse to reproduce native trees in critical danger of extinction. For a start, we have planted the first 500 trees in the greenhouse. These trees are now ready to be transplanted to their final place in the Reserve. 


But we need your help.

We are asking for your help to transplant the seedlings from the greenhouse to deforested areas within the Reserve and ensure their survival over the next two years.
We have also many trees in danger of extinction that have naturally grown in devastated areas  since we initiated the conservation project in the reserve.  These trees are now competing with many other species and they have very little chance to survive unless we help them with some maintenance work.

If you want to contribute, Ideally you adopt a tree for at least two years. In this way, you make sure that your tree is taken care of during the most vulnerable period of it´s lifetime.




In order to plant the trees we need to do lots of things:

Preparation of the terrain (€814)
This includes levelling and cleaning up deforested areas, preparing pathways in order to access the planted trees for maintenance.

Planting of the trees and maintenance during 2 years (€3,034)
This includes transplanting the trees, plague and illness control,watering, maintenance personnel during two years, daily inspections, reseeding...

Various materials needed during 2 years (€889)
There´s lots of stuff we need to take care of the trees, such as organic fertilizer (everything we do is organic and natural), limestone, natural water retainers, various species of native seeds, volcanic rock, gardening supplies....

Communication (€170)
To make this campaign a success we develop a website, we need hosting, images..

Various overhead (€717)
In a project like this there´s always unexpected costs, so we calculated a % for this as well. Anything that is not being used of this budget item is going straight into planting more trees!

Crowdfunding fees (€495)
The percentage that indiegogo takes is added to the budget as well. 

This brings us to a total budget of €6,119 which will allow us to plant and take care of  1,500 trees during 2 years.
As your support comes in, we immediately convert this into planting and protecting trees. As a matter of fact, we are in the Reserve right now making all the preparations needed to start planting. This is why this is a flexible campaign- the more money comes in, the more trees we plant, although our objective for now is plant  maintain 1,500 trees during 2 years. Afterwards, we plant 2,000 to 3,000 trees each year!

What´s in it for you?
People plant trees for lots of reasons. To celebrate the birth of a new family member, a birthday, to mark a special milestone in life, to honour a deceased loved one or, to save the planet or, simply, because it makes them feel good!
So besides the fact that planting a tree is a great thing, your tree, during it´s lifetime of growth, reproduction and decomposition, contribute towards ensuring biodiversity in the following ways:
  • Trees promote the return of endangered species.
  • Trees, through photosynthesis, are primarily responsible for providing part of the oxygen we breathe and remove carbon dioxide, which causes global warming leading to the dreaded greenhouse effect. Each tree absorbs about 25 kg of carbon emissions each year.
  • Trees protect the soil from erosion. Their branches and leaves stop the direct impact of water droplets. The water descends slower through the trunk or falls from the branches or leaves, so it gets more chance to infiltrate the soil. This ensures that a greater proportion of water is retained in the subsurface reserves and less water runs over the surface, reducing their erosive effect. The roots of the trees also form a network that holds the soil and helps protect it.
  • In the woods, or in areas with vegetation, surface minerals are drawn to a much lesser extent than in bare lands. In areas with few trees, few shrubs or grass, little quantities of water can form large grooves on the earth and impoverish the land – turning it sterile. The current large deserts were great forests in the past. Trees also act as a shield against the wind, another important erosive factor.
  • The trees stop the wind and keep it from dragging the materials to another place and push them hard against the very ground which favors its disintegration. The importance of wind on the landscape can be clrearly seen in places bare of vegetation such as deserts, where the sand entrainment by wind changes the dunes constantly. In many cities next to deserts trees are planted to prevent the advance of desert.
  • Forests also act positively against temperature changes, another soil destructive factor. The differences of heat and cold between day and night produce its disintegration and help accelerate the erosion process. The sun shines directly on the bare earth and increases the evaporation of water, drying the ground. In forest areas soil moisture is plentiful.
  • Trees have provided medicines for centuries, in particular against malaria, acidity, measles, lung diseases, rheumatism, influenza, and leprosy, among others....
So all this is fantastic. But we also provide unique perks, including a t-shirt, a guided visits to our reserve, and even a course for recognising and using medicinal plants.

About us
Our reserve is managed by the nonprofit organization “FUNDACIÓN RESERVA NATURAL LOS TANANEOS” which has a clear purpose of contributing to preserve the environment, fauna, flora, biodiversity and water resources of our region, and to investigate and find sustainable solutions in the use of our natural resources.
Since 2010, with an integrated team of professionals from various disciplines, united by the shared passion for nature, we have achieved these accomplishments:

Environmental Education:
¨Guardians of the Forest¨ program; a growing group of children and adults engaged in learning, care for and preserve the natural heritage, ecosystems and biodiversity of the Cesar Region.

Reforestation:
-400 fruit trees planted in 2012
-Construction of our greenhouse for the propagation of forest species in critical danger of extinction
We have allocated 170.14 hectares as Forest Reserve, where native species are protected from the pressures that human population has on them.

Conservation and recovery program Tananeo tree (Peltogyne Purpurea):
With the support of the Colombian Corporation for Agricultural Research CORPOICA.

Green building:
Construction of the ecological house ¨Los Tananeos¨. Construction began on July 1, 2013, with the celebration of a course in Bio Construction, Ecoarchitecture, bioclimate, water management and renewable energy. We have completed advanced since then 45% of the project and the goal is to finish the house in 2016.

Organic food production:
We explore different methods of sustainable agriculture in our reserve.


The reserve became an official National Reserve in Colombia, recognised by the national authorities as of February 2015. 

Other ways you can help

If you can´t contribute by donating to the campaign, you can help us in the following ways:

  • Spread the word and make some noise about out campaign- on and offline:
    #Tananeos #adoptatree #safethedryforest
    Campaign: http://igg.me/at/tananeos
    Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/LosTananeos
    Twitter: https://twitter.com/LosTananeos
  • Plant a tree in your own garden - any additional tree helps our planet!

Spread the word and make some noise about out campaign- on and offline:#Tananeos #adoptatree #safethedryforest Campaign: http://igg.me/at/tananeosFacebook: https://www.facebook.com/LosTananeosTwitter: https://twitter.com/LosTananeos

Plant a tree in your own garden - any additional tree helps our planet!

story:
The Monarch Butterfly,

Milkweed and Pollination Problems,

and How You Can Help To Make a Difference

This is our family's effort to save the Monarch Butterflies and educate the public.

Being raised in a farm I know the magic that comes from earth. As a child I played chasing butterflies outdoors and when hungry I picked a fruit; while my grandmother used the herbs for their healing properties and the vegetables and roots to make our food.
 
The real magic though, was in the wild flowers and pollinators; the bees, butterflies and hummingbirds that brought, with great beauty, everything to life.

 Now, over 30 years later, the Monarch, one of those beautiful butterflies, are close to becoming an endangered specie.

Threatened animals like elephants and lions grab all the headlines, but what’s happening to monarch butterflies is nothing short of a massacre. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service summed it up in just one grim statistic: Since 1990, about 970 million have vanished.

Statistics from the WWF shows the rapid decline of Monarch from 2003-2013

The Milkweed Problem

A butterfly's range depends more on the availability of host plants for larvae than on nectar plants for adults, so protecting larval hosts, the milkweed plant, is a priority.  Milkweed is not a favorite of farmers, though.  Once widespread throughout the U.S., the plant's range has fallen considerably due to herbicide use on corn and soybean fields in several parts of the U.S., according to WWF.

The Pollination Problem

Worldwide there is disturbing evidence that pollinating animals, like Monarch Butterflies, have suffered from loss of habitat, chemical misuse and diseases and parasites.  Federal public land management agencies are taking an active role by creating pollinator gardens that provide habitat for the monarch butterflies and our family is now adding to this effort.

What We Have Done

When my daughter and I first learned about the Monarch problem, we bought a few milkweed plants and in about 30 days we had 12 to 15 healthy adult butterflies emerging from their cocoons.  We were not so lucky with our second group, but like everything else we learned the most during this time. 

We are now keeping about 10 milkweed plants and getting many butterflies laying their eggs.  The problem is that caterpillars eat very fast, so in order for them to have enough food we have to pool the pots before the butterflies lay too many eggs.  If too many caterpillars are born they will not have enough milkweed to eat and they will not make it to adults. 

With some knowledge base and minimum resources we have helped the healthy metamorphosis of roughly 80 Monarch butterflies from March to June. 

The Plan Is to Make a Big Difference:

  • Lease about 1 acre of land close to schools and nature parks

  • Increase the amount of milkweed plants to 100

  • Begin to grow our own native milkweed and pollen flowers and increase the garden

  • Reach out to city departments to request permission to plant milkweed and pollen flowers in public land

  • Have a greenhouse to protect and separate the plants

  • Build a website and create a social media presence

  • Build an online store to sustain and promote the garden

  • Create an application for smart devices

  • Create brochures about the importance of the Monarch pollination and the environment and give them out at school

  • Provide lessons on how to create a butterfly garden

  • Prepare an educational school field trip

  • Provide art activities for young children

  • Have a small shop to sale products related to gardening and butterflies

  • Give milkweed plants to the children with information on how to raise their butterflies

  • Have a presence in the community activities and farmers markets 

Your Contribution

With the funds collected we will:

  1. Lease about one acre of land 

  2. Purchase seeds, milkweed and nectar plants

  3. Create printed and digital educational marketing material

  4. Reach out to city departments to request permission to plant milkweed and pollen flowers in public land

  5. Build a website and create a social media presence

  6. Build an online store to sustain and promote the garden

  7. Purchase a greenhouse

Reaching the Goal:

If we reach $17,000, that is almost half of our  goal and we will be able to:

    1. Purchase seeds, milkweed and nectar plants

    2. Create printed and digital educational marketing material

    3. Reach out to city departments to request permission to plant milkweed and pollen flowers in public land

    4. Build a website and create a social media presence

    5. Build an online store to sustain and promote the garden

If we reach  $5,000 of our goal we will be able to:

  1. Purchase seeds, milkweed and nectar plants
  2. Build a website and create a social media presence

  3. Build an online store to sustain and promote the garden

Risks and Challenges

Like in any journey we foresee the challenges:

With only a couple of vacant lands for sale and not for lease in the city we desire, our biggest challenge will be the land. 

With my negotiating skills and a few real estate friends we will try to convey our story and purpose to incite the landowners to lease the properties.

If we are not successful leasing one of those lands we will look at the surrounding cities and all of their land options. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute with funds, there are other ways you can contribute:

  • Share this link with your friends and family
  • Like us on facebook
  • Use the Indiegogo share toolbar
  • Make your own butterfly garden at home

story:
Why Build an Earthship?

                                                  

       (Earthship at Silver Lake Nature Center, Bucks County, PA)

The construction of the first earthship on a University campus takes time, patience, and most of all persistence. It started off with the desire to provide a functional example of a livable structure built off of recycled materials. And that defines an earthship!

In order to break away from a wasteful, consumer-driven lifestyle, we must first look at the place that we call home. Most homes in the United States are unsustainable due to their energy usage and construction practices.

  • 48% of most household energy usage goes toward heating and cooling (USEIA)

  • Traditional planning ignores the house’s orientation in relation to ground slope or exposure to the  sun

  • Most homes rely on city water, depleting water sources such as aquifers by using over 40,000 gallons of water per home, per year

In contrast, an earthship is a fully sustainable, off-grid structure. The larger environmental impacts of construction significantly influence the design of the structure.

What is an earthship?

The structure of an earthship is built with tires that have been pounded full of dirt. Empty cans and bottles are upcycled by incorporating them into the walls to increase insulation. The inner and outer façade is covered in cob or adobe. There is a rain catching, storing, and filtering system which supplies the building's water needs. After the water has been used in a sink or shower, the resulting greywater is sent to the indoor greenhouse to water plants. Excess water from the greenhouse is used in the toilet. Black water is sent to a solar septic tank. An earthship is designed to be completely off-grid, electricity is sourced from solar panels. As a Sustainability Science major, the idea of having Montclair University’s 20,000 students, and its surrounding communities, understand that we can live without depleting natural resources was a powerful enough motive to pursue this ambitious endeavor.

                  


                                             

 (Earthship, during construction, at Silver Lake Nature Center, Bucks County, PA)  

Who Are We?

It was obvious from the start that completing this project would not be possible without a dedicated group of environmentally conscious people working with me. Therefore, an e-mail was sent out to the Earth and Environmental Science department looking for environmentally conscious students on October 10th, 2014. Over ten enthusiastic emails and three days later we had our first Environmental Club meeting where almost ten people showed up. A week later a few of us made the initial trip to Silver Lake Nature Center’s Earthship build in Bucks County, Bristol Pennsylvania. Here we met the spearhead of the first public earthship on the East coast and got the idea to run a sustainable education center demonstration building. We also met the CEO of Earthship 360, who came to give a lecture at our University two weeks later. At around this time, a club member and his friend made a clay model of an earthship, which we would use at meetings with the Dean of the College of Science and Mathematics. His support and mentorship led us to some influential relationships that have been helpful along the way. The Director of the PSEG Institute for Sustainability Studies, Montclair Township’s Sustainability Officer, MSU’s Director of Environmental Health and Safety, and the CEO of Green Building Center are just some of the influential people who have each helped in their own way. They all have mentor roles but the most important piece of our organization is the dedicated group of students who work diligently toward making this world a better place. We are all on the same sustainable page, which makes working together productive and entertaining. We joke around, go on camping trips, hike and volunteer together, all while balancing our favorite hobbies, classes, jobs, and sports. The foundation was laid out clearly by the end of the spring semester and this momentum would carry us forward into the next fall.

                                         

                         

Many strides were made during the first school year, but with a fundraising plan, we would be primed  to bring this proposal to our University President. The budget estimate starts at $300,000 and fundraising that type of money is a daunting task for a newly chartered environmental club.  At the end of last spring, we submitted a proposal for an award from the United States Green Building council for their Innovative Sustainability Initiative category. Finding out that we will be given an honorable mention at the USGBC’s Emerald Award Gala made us feel proud of everything we have accomplished thus far. It felt as if this award set the stage for the future of this project and there was no stopping us now! This journey has taught us a lot in one year, but we are looking forward to taking the next big step and getting the University’s approval to make this dream a reality. With this much perseverance and manpower fueling this project, we are like a maglev train traveling at 4,000 miles per hour on clean energy!

                       

                         


Recognition

Our Project has received much acknowledgement by the professional sustainability community. One of our proudest achievements so far is the honorable mention we received from the United States Green Building Council, which was awarded to us at their New Jersey chapter gala in october. This further exemplifies our efforts and commitment to this project.

                                                                         

                                         


News Articles

The Montclarion

Montclair State University News

Tapintomontclair.com

NorthJersey.com


What We Need & What You Get

We are aiming to fundraise $50,000 as seed money in order to begin collecting materials,paying for labor, site prep, and design plans. Any little bit helps, but donations over $100 will recieve a social media shot out  and donations over $500 will have their name embedded inside the canned wall. For our larger donations of $1,000 and $5,000 we will have their names on a tile or after a system respectively.  Reaching our goal will also allow us to pursue additional funding from private donors, foundations, and corporations. 


                                      \

Our University recently constructed a LEED silver Center for Environmental and Life Sciences, home of our PSEG Institute for Sustainability Studies and Passaic River Institute and degrees in Sustainability Science. Our MSU’s Sustainability Center: Inspired by earthship would compliment our University's goal of going carbon neutral by 2050. Whether you can or cannot make a donation, sharing this project on your favorite social media outlets will help us get the word out, which is what ultimately counts. Please come be a part of something greater than us, something that is working towards creating a better world for future generations, something truly sustainable!

story:
Welcome to our campaign!

Introduction

Hey guys!

We’re a group of 17-year old students from the Liverpool Blue Coat School, and this July, we will be embarking on an adventure in the splendiferous country of South Africa.

With our combined passion and interest fuelling our desire to see and experience such diverse ecosystems, we hope that with the help of Operation Wallacea (an environmental research organisation) and you, we can educate ourselves on conservation in South Africa.

Cost Breakdown

Such an opportunity, unfortunately, comes at a great cost. The cost for this expedition has been set at £2,500 in addition to various equipment costs per person. As students, this cost comes as a great burden and we would be grateful of any help that you could offer. 

Itinerary

If all goes to plan, we should be departing from Liverpool, UK on the 9th of July and upon arrival at Johannesburg O.R. Tambo International Airport we will proceed to Kruger National Park where we will spend the first of our two-week conservation expedition.

Here, we will be conducting fieldwork and collecting data that will ultimately be used to:

  • Quantify the impact of elephants around artificial and natural waterholes.
  • Calculate carrying capacity of reserves for elephants.
  • Monitor the distribution of large herbivores and predators.
  • Complete annual surveys of winter bird community structure and density in areas of habitat with differing levels of elephant impact.

The second week, aptly dubbed "Marine Week", will have our group travelling to Sodwana Bay in Kwa Zulu Natal, South Africa and completing a PADI Open Water dive training course which involves a combination of theory lessons, confined water dives, and open water dives to gain an official SCUBA qualification.

Operation Wallacea

Operation Wallacea describe themselves as:
"a network of academics from European and North American universities, who design and implement biodiversity and conservation management research programmes."
"Research is supported by students who join the programme, to strengthen their CV or resume or collect data for a dissertation or thesis. Academics benefit from funding for high quality fieldwork enabling them to publish papers in peer reviewed journals which will inevitably help in efforts to preserve the structural integrity of one of the most precious of ecosystems. This model enables the collection of large temporal and spatial datasets used for assessing the effectiveness of conservation management interventions."
~  www.opwall.com
The South African expeditions are run alongside a South African NGO, Wildlife and Ecological Investments (WEI), who provide support for conservation managers in their fight against biodiversity loss, and help to protect the natural resources on which we all depend.

About Us

Now, it's time to meet us - the loveable scamps behind this campaign. Find out a little bit about each and every one of us and find out why we're all so excited to go on this trip!

Final Thanks

Thank you so much again from all of us, and on behalf of everyone at Operation Wallacea for taking the time to make it this far in our story.
If you can't donate, a share on Facebook, Twitter or any other social media site would be really appreciated.
Help get the conversation about conservation started!

Let's make this happen!

Let's make this happen!

story:
A brief summary

My name is Sebastian Cruft. I am the inventor of the HUMO™.  I'm retired now, but I worked for 35 years as a Director of a small family company. Although I was never trained as an engineer, I spent many years in a factory, specifying machinery and  adapting off-the-shelf machines to work to our purposes. I also learned how important it is that products:

a. do something people really want, and

b. do it effectively and reliably.

For 30 years I have had progressive MS, and I'm now full-time in a wheelchair, with only one working hand. This is very frustrating, and prevents me from physically making anything. In the past, I often wondered whether I should give up the HUMO™ project - but I feel it is so close to success and has such great potential that I don't want to stop. 

I have always felt that there is a gap in the market - a truly versatile and efficient form of human powered transport, which uses the strength in a human body more effectively to provide a simple, cheap, safe way to get around, with a bit of room for the things which are needed for ordinary life - shopping, a briefcase, a violin, a community nurse's bag for bandages, blood-testing etc...

We want to make the HUMO™ available as widely as possible by building a community of customers and partners to co-create and innovate, spreading HUMO™ ideas as far and wide as possible. We see endless potential uses around the world.

First, we need to build a new, lightweight, foldable prototype that will become our launchpad.

What We Need & What You Get

HUMO™ prototypes have been built in the past and have successfully proved the principles behind the revolutionary crank design. However, they were made from 40mm box-section steel, and the lighter of the two weighed 80kg - that's eight times heavier than a standard bicycle.

This new prototype, based on a 21kg folding aluminium frame, will be much more portable, easier to secure, and faster, traveling at upwards of 25mph.

Our first priority is to build the aluminium prototype, which we estimate will cost $10,000 - we will regularly report back on progress through social media.

Additional funds will go towards:

1. Developing the HUMO™ Community

To maximise co-operation we want to develop a more interactive environment with forums, live chats and document sharing, so that all of our learning and developments can be shared for the benefit of all.

2. Building an even lighter, faster plastic prototype

With more funds, we will jump straight to a plastic prototype, for which we will need mould designs. This would be a bonus but is far from a necessity.

3. Preparing CAD drawings of other products using the principles of the HUMO™ drive, such as 2-person, 4- and 5-person cars, light delivery vehicles, light-weight tractors and mowers, water-transporters, 2-driver ambulances etc. Your suggestions will be welcome, and, within our budget, we will design anything harmless which we feel is practical, sharing the designs on the community.

Perks

To thank you for your generosity I am offering some perks - ranging from my heartfelt thanks, to a unique one-off lifetime 50% discount on a commercially produced HUMO™. Our most generous funders will have the opportunity to come over to Devon in the UK, to see the prototype being tested and to be one of the very first people in the world to drive one.

The Result

The HUMO™ offers many significant benefits over both cars and bicycles, including:

  • the environmental benefits of pollution-free human powered transport
  • greatly reduced damage in an impact (due to lower weight and greater stability)
  • avoid parking costs (can be kept indoors like a bike) 
  • great visibility from the upright riding position
  • additional stability from 4 wheels
  • protection from the elements (lightweight, high visibility weatherproof shell)
  • no need to dismount when stopped at a red light
  • significantly lower purchase price than a car
  • no car or road tax
  • low maintenance and insurance costs
  • you get fit using one
  • they are great fun!

To maximise the success of the HUMO™ I have assembled a team of 'champions', all experts in their fields of Engineering, Management, IT and Marketing. The champions have helped me get the campaign off the ground, and will continue to be involved with the HUMO™ project as it evolves and expands.

Risks & Challenges

The previous prototypes that I have developed (at my own cost) have been too heavy, but they have proved that this revolutionary crank system actually works. The most significant task now is to keep the prototype as light as possible; we are looking forward to sending you films of a HUMO™ cruising under human power at the sort of speeds (25mph+) which will be sufficient for everyday life.  

The first lightweight prototype will be built from aluminium. This is cheap to produce, environmentally sound and easy to fabricate. Excluding the cranks, the majority of the drive train and wheels will be provided by parts from off-the-shelf bicycles, keeping our costs as low as possible while maintaining accessibility.

It is hoped that this will produce a prototype that can form the blueprint for future development, the designs of which can be shared with partners and other innovators throughout the HUMO™ Community.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word! 
  • Come to us with your ideas!
  • If you are a member of any environmental pressure group, academic organisation, college fraternity or school where the threats of global warming or environmental pollution are taken seriously, please pass on our message
  • You could build your own HUMO™, following the HUMO™ philosophy (please see our website - www.humocars.com), and let us know how you're doing
  • Become a volunteer Humo champion

And put simply, that is all that I can ask. I believe in this project with all of my heart, and hope that if other people can imagine it in the same way, they will be as enthused about this revolutionary transport as I am.
story_txt:
A brief summary
My name is Sebastian Cruft. I am the inventor of the HUMO™.  I'm retired now, but I worked for 35 years as a Director of a small family company. Although I was never trained as an engineer, I spent many years in a factory, specifying machinery and  adapting off-the-shelf machines to work to our purposes. I also learned how important it is that products:
a. do something people really want, and
b. do it effectively and reliably.
For 30 years I have had progressive MS, and I'm now full-time in a wheelchair, with only one working hand. This is very frustrating, and prevents me from physically making anything. In the past, I often wondered whether I should give up the HUMO™ project - but I feel it is so close to success and has such great potential that I don't want to stop. 
I have always felt that there is a gap in the market - a truly versatile and efficient form of human powered transport, which uses the strength in a human body more effectively to provide a simple, cheap, safe way to get around, with a bit of room for the things which are needed for ordinary life - shopping, a briefcase, a violin, a community nurse's bag for bandages, blood-testing etc...
We want to make the HUMO™ available as widely as possible by building a community of customers and partners to co-create and innovate, spreading HUMO™ ideas as far and wide as possible. We see endless potential uses around the world.
First, we need to build a new, lightweight, foldable prototype that will become our launchpad.

no car or road tax
low maintenance and insurance costs
you get fit using one
they are great fun!

To maximise the success of the HUMO™ I have assembled a team of 'champions', all experts in their fields of Engineering, Management, IT and Marketing. The champions have helped me get the campaign off the ground, and will continue to be involved with the HUMO™ project as it evolves and expands.

story:
Help bee the change plant the forage for pollinators in solar fields. 

Most solar fields are planted with grass or stone, we feel that this is a missed opportunity. bee the change places a diverse array of plantings in and around the solar field, which increases plant productivity within and beyond the field and supports downstream species who rely on that biodiversity, such as birds, fish, wildlife, and human beings.

What we need:

Your support will allow us to purchase seed and plants and to expand across New England, hoping to expand in the path of the migratory pollinators like the hummingbird and monarch.

Next spring we will be placing beehives and teaching beekeeping in prisons, hiring released offenders as we expand. Please consider supporting us, and get this cool stuff:

  • Donate $15 to receive a jar of bee the change honey 
  • Donate $25 to receive a bee-shirt
  • Donate $50 for a jar of honey + 2 bee-shirts
  • Donate $1,000 for an acre of land
  • Donate $5,000 for a solar field 

The Impact

Our first field, installed in May 2016, is the equivalent in area to 3,624 homes with 12 X 6 pollinator gardens. And several more fields are under construction at this moment.

A survey of the pollinator population in our first year at the South Ridge field in Middlebury demonstrated 34 unique pollinator encounters in a 15 minute period. One year later, surveying the same plots, we encountered 174 unique pollinators in 15 minutes. That impact will increase the productivity of plants beyond the boundaries of the solar field and support downstream species who rely on that productivity- birds, fish, other wildlife and, of course, human beings.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute towards the financial goal, we'd love your help in spreading the word about our campaign. Please share our Indiegogo, Facebook, or website page! 

  • A sample post:
    • Planting the forage for natural pollinators in Vermont solar fields: http://www.beethechangehoney.com
    • Read about the Kiernan's bright idea to pair solar fields and bee hives! http://www.addisonindependent.com/201609bright-idea-kiernan-pairs-solar-arrays-and-bees  

Visit us online at: http://www.beethechangehoney.com

story:
Our Goal:

We, as a team of experienced craftsmen on the one hand and dedicated young scientists on the other have committed ourselves to finding a simple solution to a world wide problem.

And we do believe we have found it.

The Bottle Boat, will demonstrate this and will become the nexus, we hope, for others to see our ideas, improve on them and take them worldwide.

Anyone who is on a trekking holiday and who has seen our video will know how at the end of the day they can convert their discarded bottles into a small building panel, for the next person to add to. 

And the next.

If they return a year later they might well find a small animal shelter has been constructed. Or the wall of a house that is light, waterproof and earthquake resistant.

It can be done.

 

Our Resources:

We already have premises in Camden, a piano restoration workshop, and have been offered a huge amount of building space and  recycled materials by Market Tech, the new owners of Camden Lock Market. 
As the founders of Camden Piano Rescue we have achieved several world records for charity in the UK, Ukraine, and India. 
We have a small army of environmentally dedicated volunteers who will help us construct our project, the full size replica of a Viking Longboat.

This will be constructed with recycled materials and volunteer help and costs will be minimal.
 
Funds Required:
What we need is funds to purchase the wide beam support vessel that will house the conference room and media room, disabled toilets and necessary ramps, life jackets, and ancillary equipment required for an open deck Viking Longboat. 

 

The Camden Market area is extraordinarily busy and receives an average of 500 thousand visitors a week.  Our project has received media interest and the BBC started filming on September 8th. 
 

The Team:

 

 

 

Previous Projects: 

 

2014:  Delivered gift of Piano from Camden Market to Lingshed Village School,  Zanskar Range, Himalayas. North India, through Singela Pass at 5,500 metres.

 

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

2015: Rescued and restored original piano used by Jack White on the White Stripes Elephant Recording. Item auctioned for £5,300 for the benefit of charity, Barka UK, under the direction of Ola Ciurlik.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
April 2016: Mended and recorded last remaining piano in abandoned town of Chernobyl, Ukraine on 30th anniversary of nuclear power station meltdown. April 26th 1986. Song and video "Last Piano Chernobyl".
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
July, 2016: Built 1st recycled plastic bottle greenhouse in Himalayas.

 

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

 

Planned for November 20th, 2016: Music2Moputo (Mozambique).       Organised by Ann and Anthony Holme, filmed by BBC.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

story:
La Iniciativa

 

Nuestra iniciativa tiene como objetivo la realización de un circuito continuo senderista, por etapas, aprovechando los senderos y pistas existentes en nuestro fascinante Parque Natural de las Sierras Subbéticanas; en él ya existen una serie de senderos discontinuos que muestran, parcialmente, la belleza y esplendor que atesora este espacio natural inigualable; el hecho de crear una vía continua, que muestre sus espacios más emblemáticos y sobresalientes, no solo contribuiría de manera decisiva a ampliar el conocimiento del mismo y a la cooperación de sus pueblos sino que además traería una serie de oportunidades de empleo y de beneficios económicos de gran calado para toda la comunidad de la Subbética, reforzando el turismo de toda la zona y recuperando nuestro paisaje para el caminante, reencontrándolo con nuestro sistemas de vida tradicional; devolviéndolo al camino el concepto de lugar de encuentro, de cooperación, de intercambio de oportunidades y de convivencia.

 

Características 

 

Entre los elementos que caracterizan nuestra iniciativa están:

1- Patrullas Subbeticanas que serán la encargadas de restaurar y mantener todo el circuito auxiliar e informar a los usuarios de el mismo, velando en todo momento  para que los usuarios cumplan las normas de buenas practicas que se establezcan a lo largo del circuito, minimizando así posibles conflictos que vayan en perjuicios de los propietarios tradicionales o del propio Parque Natural.

2- Fomento de la Educación Medio Ambiental, a través de la implantación en los diferentes centros educativos de la comarca de la  " Semana Subbeticana "que servirán a nuestros jóvenes como aulario de la naturaleza, brindándoles la oportunidad de conocer mejor sus tierras y sus gentes ayudándoles a estrechar lazos con su mundo natural y rural más cercano.

 

3- Fomento de áreas recreativas adecuadas para pernoctar, acampar etc., donde estén garantizadas la accesibilidad universal.

 

4- Ofrecer un destino turístico de calidad, adaptando y ordenado los recursos turísticos que tiene la zona, e  incrementar de esta manera la competitividad turística, de forma conjunta de todos los pueblos y aldeas de las sierras subbéticas.

 

5- Incrementar la oferta deportiva y de turismo activo, mostrando al visitante la riqueza paisajística, natural, cultural y monumental de los pueblos y aldeas de las Sierras Subbéticas.

 

6- Educar en la práctica responsable  y sostenible del turismo medio ambiental.

story:
Il QK Project in sintesi

Il QK Project è l'ambizioso progetto di una rete mondiale di Ecovillaggi.

 

Un Libro e un Video per la promozione del QK Project

Ho redatto un libro di oltre 600 pagine, Reinventare il mondo. Tentativo di applicazione del paradigma quanto-kabbalistico alla società, un'opera colossale, che descrive le basi teoriche di questo meraviglioso e rivoluzionario progetto. Il libro costituisce il veicolo mediante il quale diffondere la conoscenza del progetto.

Vogliamo stampare le prime 250 copie in maniera autonoma e realizzare un video virale per la promozione di gioielli, la cui vendita servirà a finanziare la documentazione necessaria alla creazione del primo Ecovillaggio.

 

Costi e Finalità

La vendita della versione ebook del libro è finalizzata a coprire le spese della stampa cartacea e la realizzazione di un video professionale.

La stampa di 250 libri ammonta a 3500 euro di spesa. Ciò significa che dobbiamo vendere almeno 200 ebook per riuscire a coprire le spese.

Mentre la realizzazione del video ammonta a 2000 euro.

 

Ci date una mano?

Per un'offerta di 15 euro, riceverete l'ebook  "Reinventare il mondo. Tentativo di applicazione del paradigma quanto-kabbalistico alla società" e in omaggio "Le tre Religioni monoteiste secondo la Kabbalah".

Per ogni offerta di 50 euro, riceverete invece questi 7 ebook:

 

Riceverete gli ebook in 3 formati differenti:

pdf (formato ad alta risoluzione, ottimo per la stampa)

mobi (formato Kindle)

ePub (formato adatto a tutti i dispositivi elettronici)

 

GRAZIE!!

A nome mio e della nostra equipe GRAZIE dal più profondo del cuore

del vostro sostegno e contributo.

Insieme possiamo davvero incamminarci verso un mondo migliore...

 

vostra Shazarahel

story:
Let Us Introduce Ourselves

The Concerned Professional Engineers (CPE) are a small group of professional engineers living in British Columbia, Canada.  Together we have many decades of experience in the design, construction and operation of large projects for the extraction and transportation of natural resources like coal and oil.

We share a deep concern for the environment and the future of this coast, this country and this planet.  With our backgrounds we are keenly aware of the inherent conflict between environmental protection and resource development.

We understand that we cannot end our dependence on resources tomorrow, and that it is important to propose practical, achievable solutions to these problems that strike an acceptable balance between economic development and risk to the environment.  We are not opposed to the development and export of natural resources, but we feel very strongly that these projects must be done in as safe and responsible manner as possible, with a full accounting of the risks and visibility to the public.

Our focus is that we want the public to know about the high risk decisions that were made by the federal government in approving the Kinder Morgan’s Trans-mountain Expansion Project.  This project will increase the tanker traffic in Burrard Inlet from 5 to 34 vessels per month.  This increase has not had a proper risk assessment on two counts;

  • A risk analysis on collision with the existing bridges has not been done.
  • The 10% risk of a major spill of 8.25 million liters in 50 years has not been properly analyzed;
    • The government has given no explanation as to why they’ve accepted this risk.
    • There is no evidence that this assessment has been peer reviewed and compared with other acceptable risks.

We want to spread awareness on what risk is and what risks are associated with this project.

The key is to reduce risk to acceptable levels.  The basis on which the federal government approved the expansion is 5 times the risk we accept for earthquakes and 20 times riskier that what we accept for new bridge construction.

The concerns we have were brought to the federal government and the National Energy Board (NEB), but were ignored.  We have tried to make a legal appeal to the courts, but have been turned down because we don’t have the status on an intervenor (denied to us by NEB).  

 

Our Plan and How You Can Help!

CPE is looking to raise $10,000 to assist in continuing efforts to press the federal government in reassessing the risks associated with the Kinder Morgan Expansion.  We will use these donations to support the CPE team and focus on the following;

  • We wish to assist organizations who have brought an action to oppose the expansion in the Federal Appeal Court.
  • We wish to continue our dialogue with the owners of the Railway Bridge (CN) and the Ironworkers Memorial Bridge (Minister of Transportation and Infrastructure of BC).  The bridge owners are, at the present time, carrying out a risk analysis of collision with their bridges resulting from the increased tanker traffic.
  • We are working with the owners of the bridges to ensure that they are implementing proper risk analysis for the increased tanker traffic.  This would ensure that if the risks are too high (above those deemed acceptable for other projects), that the bridge owners are doing what needs to be done to mitigate the higher risks.
  • CPE is writing up a work plan for the engineers assigned to the task of deciding the safety of the Second Narrows Bridges, and will take the work plan to the owners’ engineers responsible for the bridges.
  • CPE feels the only way to ensure that this job is done properly is to see that the bridge owners carry out a proper risk analysis and be open and transparent about it.
  • We will continue to be in contact and work with organizations concerned with the safety of the project by sharing our engineering expertise.
  • We need your help to spread the message of the actions we are taking to raise public awareness and share through social media.

 

The Impact, Risks, & Challenges

Evidence shows that changing the port location is the best way to minimize risk to both people and to the environment.  Unfortunately, cost and time for approvals have gotten in the way of making the safest location decision. The federal Department of Fisheries and the Minister of Environment (in 1987) rated the Eastern Burrard Inlet as the riskiest (unsafest) location from which to ship petroleum products.  Roberts Bank (Deltaport) is many times safer than the Eastern Burrard Inlet. We also think that our federal government should make the effort to provide a terminal and export route that are as safe as possible.  The studies that were done in 1987 showed the safest port location to be Port Simpson, where sailing time from the port to the open ocean is only a half an hour (30 km N of Prince Rupert).  

It is essential that the public understand the risks associated with the current decision, how to minimize these risks, and that the information needs to be passed on and enforced by the government to do a proper risk assessment before approving this or other similar projects.

The purpose of this campaign is to get this message out to the public, to support the intervenors who have status (who are able to legally challenge the federal government's decision), and to support the continuing costs in dialoguing with the owners of the bridges to fulfill their responsibility to provide the maximum protection possible for their bridges.

In conclusion, with your donations, CPE plans;

  • to assist those who are publicly campaigning against this decision,
  • provide them with public arguments on the high risks, and work to educate the public that if there were an incident with the bridges and spilled oil, the public will end up paying the price to clean up the spill.
  • create a work plan to submit to the Second Narrows Bridge owners, to use as a standard for a safe risk assessment, and what steps should occur to assure safety should a tanker hit one or both bridges in an accident.
  • continue to circulate information and educate the public on the safety concerns for the environment that this expansion will imply.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help.  Please pass this campaign onto your friends, colleagues, and family to spread the word and help create a Safer BC.

Shareables;

  • Indiegogo link
  • Website: concernedengineers.org
  • Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/concernedpeng/
  • You Tube:
    • Second Narrows Bridge Animation, Could Tankers Collide with the Second Narrows Bridges, https://youtu.be/6N9WCm-QRpo
    • Expanded Burnaby Tank Farm Increased Risks, Only One Bite in 100 Bears, but They Don't Come in Order, https://youtu.be/tOyceZiLF-Y

  • Relevant Articles:

    • The Global Mail Interactive Video Article, Weigh Anchor; https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/british-columbia/kinder-morgan-trans-mountain-pipeline-bc-coast/article35043172/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/british-columbia/kinder-morgan-trans-mountain-pipeline-bc-coast/article35043172/

    • The Global Mail Story Behind the Weigh Anchor Interactive Video Article, On the Trail of an Oil Tanker, https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/british-columbia/a-tankers-journey-through-bc-waters-carrying-oil-from-the-kinder-morganpipeline/article35070386/

    • The Vancouver Sun Article, Province Looks at Ability of Burrard Inlet Bridges to Handle Oil Tanker Collision, http://vancouversun.com/news/local-news/province-looks-at-ability-of-burrard-inlet-bridges-to-handle-oil-tanker-collisions

Let Us Introduce Ourselves
The Concerned Professional Engineers (CPE) are a small group of professional engineers living in British Columbia, Canada.  Together we have many decades of experience in the design, construction and operation of large projects for the extraction and transportation of natural resources like coal and oil.
We share a deep concern for the environment and the future of this coast, this country and this planet.  With our backgrounds we are keenly aware of the inherent conflict between environmental protection and resource development.
We understand that we cannot end our dependence on resources tomorrow, and that it is important to propose practical, achievable solutions to these problems that strike an acceptable balance between economic development and risk to the environment.  We are not opposed to the development and export of natural resources, but we feel very strongly that these projects must be done in as safe and responsible manner as possible, with a full accounting of the risks and visibility to the public.
Our focus is that we want the public to know about the high risk decisions that were made by the federal government in approving the Kinder Morgan’s Trans-mountain Expansion Project.  This project will increase the tanker traffic in Burrard Inlet from 5 to 34 vessels per month.  This increase has not had a proper risk assessment on two counts;

A risk analysis on collision with the existing bridges has not been done.
The 10% risk of a major spill of 8.25 million liters in 50 years has not been properly analyzed;
The government has given no explanation as to why they’ve accepted this risk.
There is no evidence that this assessment has been peer reviewed and compared with other acceptable risks.



We want to spread awareness on what risk is and what risks are associated with this project.
The key is to reduce risk to acceptable levels.  The basis on which the federal government approved the expansion is 5 times the risk we accept for earthquakes and 20 times riskier that what we accept for new bridge construction.
The concerns we have were brought to the federal government and the National Energy Board (NEB), but were ignored.  We have tried to make a legal appeal to the courts, but have been turned down because we don’t have the status on an intervenor (denied to us by NEB).  
 
Our Plan and How You Can Help!
CPE is looking to raise $10,000 to assist in continuing efforts to press the federal government in reassessing the risks associated with the Kinder Morgan Expansion.  We will use these donations to support the CPE team and focus on the following;

We wish to assist organizations who have brought an action to oppose the expansion in the Federal Appeal Court.
We wish to continue our dialogue with the owners of the Railway Bridge (CN) and the Ironworkers Memorial Bridge (Minister of Transportation and Infrastructure of BC).  The bridge owners are, at the present time, carrying out a risk analysis of collision with their bridges resulting from the increased tanker traffic.
We are working with the owners of the bridges to ensure that they are implementing proper risk analysis for the increased tanker traffic.  This would ensure that if the risks are too high (above those deemed acceptable for other projects), that the bridge owners are doing what needs to be done to mitigate the higher risks.
CPE is writing up a work plan for the engineers assigned to the task of deciding the safety of the Second Narrows Bridges, and will take the work plan to the owners’ engineers responsible for the bridges.
CPE feels the only way to ensure that this job is done properly is to see that the bridge owners carry out a proper risk analysis and be open and transparent about it.
We will continue to be in contact and work with organizations concerned with the safety of the project by sharing our engineering expertise.
We need your help to spread the message of the actions we are taking to raise public awareness and share through social media.

 
The Impact, Risks, & Challenges
Evidence shows that changing the port location is the best way to minimize risk to both people and to the environment.  Unfortunately, cost and time for approvals have gotten in the way of making the safest location decision. The federal Department of Fisheries and the Minister of Environment (in 1987) rated the Eastern Burrard Inlet as the riskiest (unsafest) location from which to ship petroleum products.  Roberts Bank (Deltaport) is many times safer than the Eastern Burrard Inlet. We also think that our federal government should make the effort to provide a terminal and export route that are as safe as possible.  The studies that were done in 1987 showed the safest port location to be Port Simpson, where sailing time from the port to the open ocean is only a half an hour (30 km N of Prince Rupert).  
It is essential that the public understand the risks associated with the current decision, how to minimize these risks, and that the information needs to be passed on and enforced by the government to do a proper risk assessment before approving this or other similar projects.
The purpose of this campaign is to get this message out to the public, to support the intervenors who have status (who are able to legally challenge the federal government's decision), and to support the continuing costs in dialoguing with the owners of the bridges to fulfill their responsibility to provide the maximum protection possible for their bridges.
In conclusion, with your donations, CPE plans;

to assist those who are publicly campaigning against this decision,
provide them with public arguments on the high risks, and work to educate the public that if there were an incident with the bridges and spilled oil, the public will end up paying the price to clean up the spill.
create a work plan to submit to the Second Narrows Bridge owners, to use as a standard for a safe risk assessment, and what steps should occur to assure safety should a tanker hit one or both bridges in an accident.
continue to circulate information and educate the public on the safety concerns for the environment that this expansion will imply.
 Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help.  Please pass this campaign onto your friends, colleagues, and family to spread the word and help create a Safer BC.

story:
Bref résumé

E-cover => "Environmental Cover"

Siège => Dakar (Sénégal) 


Mission => Utiliser les ressources (déchets) locales pour faire des produits locaux par les africains eux mêmes. 

Point de départ => La gamme des RE-tires, produits fais à base de Pneus dont les E-tiles (carreaux et revêtement de sols).

Cible => Administrations, entreprises et particuliers qui veulent décorer les espaces extérieurs avec des carreaux personnalisables et écologiques.


              

Des carreaux amortissant, amovibles et écologiques pour vos espaces extérieurs.  


Des revêtement de sols pour aires de jeux pour enfants

Des revêtements de sols pour terrains de Basket, Tennis et pistes d'athlétismes. 

Des revêtements de sols pour les devantures de vos maisons.


Des allées pour vos Jardins 


Des pose-pieds pour la devanture de vos maisons.

Des dessous pour vos pots de fleurs

Des semelles de chaussures.


Pourquoi? => Débarasser la ville des pneus présents dans chaque coin de rue et qui la rendent insalubre. 


Valeur Ajoutée : 

=> Nouveauté en Afrique de l'ouest

=> Amélioration de la gestion des déchets en Afrique

=> Carreaux et revêtements de sols amovible, la résistance, anti-dérapant,  amortissant,  personnalisable et écologique.  


Ce dont nous avons besoin et ce que vous obtenez


Problème => Moyens de production Contraignant (Fabrication Manuelle)



Besoin => 10mille $  

pour acheter la logistique adéquate pour optimiser notre production.


Ce que vous obtenez => Des contreparties intéressantes et la satisfaction de savoir que vous contribuez indirectement à la sauvegarde de l'environnement.

  • L'impact

La réalisation d'E-cover impactera:


Social:  
=> Création de nouveaux emplois
=> Développement de nouvelles habitudes de consommation. 

Environnement: 
=> Diminution d’émissions de CO2 qui favorisent le réchauffement planétaire
=> Substituant écologique au ciment et au sable utilisé pour les carreaux normaux
=> Meilleure gestion des déchets. 

Economie: 
=> Utilisation de produits recyclés par les collectivités locales dans l’aménagement des voiries
=> Augmentation de la valeur ajoutée sur les pneus usés
=> Réduction du taux du chômage
=> Diminution radicale de l'importation de carreaux
=> Accroître les exportations et développement du  "Consommer Local".

  • Risques et défis

Le Crowdfunding,  une alternative au financement classique. 

Risques => Objectif financier important et méconnaissance du concept dans le contexte Sénégalais.

Défi =>  ADAPTER le Crowdfunding au contexte local


D'autres façons d'aider

Partagez au max autour de vous et aidez nous à concrétiser notre solution.
